POST: What are people using for HIPAA compliant phone/texting systems?
We currently are using Google voice, but definitely are growing out of it and need a more comprehensive and better system. I did a demo with a company called Quo (formerly called open phone) and I was really impressed with them. Loved their features and everything really seemed great, but then when I started doing some digging and reading reviews, there were too many recent ones that were poor and has made me want to reconsider. 

We have four people that all need to access the phone and we need to keep texts and voice messages organized so things are not getting dropped.

COMMENT 1: Interesting, I actually started with Iplum and had a hard time with it. I found a call quality to be poor when I was out and about, and the whole phone tree set up was so confusing . I had a hard time reaching anybody from Customer Service. That was like five years ago though so maybe they have improved Ôøº

COMMENT 2: Update: currently transitioning to quo‚Ä¶. I‚Äôll keep you posted how it goes!

POST: What are mobile or new businesses doing for fax numbers? Does everyone have one?

I started off fully mobile and now have transitioned to hybrid practice (I rent space at a redlight, sauna, cold plunge, hot tub spa). I have never had a fax number but as we grow I have had a couple of doctors offices ask for my fax number to send documents.

POST: I am SAHM of 10 months old, not planning to join work for atleast next 6 months, But m stressed out a lot at home and thinking if I can start something from home like stretching sessions and wellness which will not include skilled services.

My question is what can I do to legally start these services at my home, do I need to get certification in stretching, then I start?

COMMENT 1: Why would you need a stretching certificate if you're a PT? You need liability insurance and can do anything within your scope and practice.

COMMENT 2: Why not do virtual PT sessions and market in Indiana 
$50+ for 30 min visits

POST: OK, are you brainiacs out there? Figure this one out

Wednesday  afternoon

slipped on let‚Äôs just say a banana peel not sure what it was. I did not fall. I did not have any impact. I caught myself and my final position of my leg when I caught myself was foot flat,  knee to about 50 degrees , flexion internal rotation of the hip and adduction of the hip 

For several days, I‚Äôve had super patella swelling , some point tenderness around the fibular head and on the femorsl condyle  anterio-lateral. 

This morning I wake up with bruising on my fibular head , on the lateral tibia proximal  right next to the fibrillar head and on the femoral condo, not on the patella  and a smaller lighter bruise on the medial tibia condyle

I‚Äôve had difficulty with weight-bearing until it gets warmed up and then I have no problem with flexion extension weight-bearing just pivoting. I have no trouble at all doing quad sets since the beginning!

Can go up on left tiptoes no problem

This swelling in half what it was

COMMENT 1: No pain ascending stairs

Descending discomfort at full flexion..likely swelling

COMMENT 2: I am now 48 hours past injury and the only symptom I‚Äôm having is discomfort in the

POST: Had a meeting with a large primary care practice (over 3,000 patients). They had a PT clinic in these 2 rooms for over 5 years and that practice led to open their own space elsewhere. They want me to sublease the space (the price seems quite high to me at $2k/month for these 2 teeny rooms). 

My thought is to offer a PT being on site 1 afternoon per week to see referrals as walk ins for screens and could schedule follow up's for that time at a fraction of that rent or maybe a % of revenue. 

I have owned my practice for over 10 years and am 75% mobile and have another much larger brick and mortar clinic on the other side of town at which I see patients 2 days per week. 

I love the idea of getting into primary care but not sure this is a good fit. Thoughts?

COMMENT 1: I have 5 rooms in my office and the rent is $4350/month I live in Fort Worth Tx. The goal is to hire MT to work with me. But while I'm building my business I have other people renting the other offices (laser hair removal, Functional Med Nurse practiciner, esthetician, infrared sauna room, and bodywork) one day a week I have some one renting my office too. What I don't have is 3000 potential clients walking pas

POST: Just starting my cash based business. I gave a patient my superbill with my EIN. She submitted to UHC and they're requesting a TIN not an EIN. I'm an individual owner LLC so I thought I just used my SSN on my taxes. I don't have a TIN, and I don't really want to put my SSN on my superbills. Any recommendations?

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôm thinking the insurance company is mistaken, if you have an EIN. All claims for my business for 5 years have only ever used the business EIN, as we had applied for that.

COMMENT 2: As I understand it, there are several kinds of TINs (Tax ID Number), including your SSN (social security number) and EIN. Therefore, your EIN *is* your TIN.

POST: Looking for some advice. For those of you who started a side hustle while working FT and then transitioned to your business FT‚Ä¶ At what point did you drop the full time job? 

I‚Äôve been seeing 12-15 patients a week on my own while also working 35-40 hrs at my full time gig and I feel like I‚Äôm barely treading water. üòÖ 

I‚Äôm afraid to quit because of losing my insurance, and the fear of just relying on my business as income. Any guidance is appreciated. üôÇ

COMMENT 1: 3 months

COMMENT 2: The time is now :) 12-15 is a great start! Be prepared that it can be financially tough for the first 6 months or so, but you've already got a good base. I also agree with others that if you weren't working the other job you could put full effort into your business. ‚ù§Ô∏è

POST: Have a PT who is pregnant and is going to be taking maternity leave.

She doesn‚Äôt qualify for FMLA as she just started working 5 months ago. But we do have paid maternity leaveve

My question: we offer 6 weeks of maternity leave that‚Äôs paid. How do I go about asking her how long she plans on taking off? Like if she wanted to take more after those 6 weeks. Just so we have a start back date that we can transition her patients back to her. Do we go ahead and set that now?

COMMENT 1: YES - talk now. Just know that plans may change. But, have an idea in your head of how things may/may not play out. 

Talk with her, as if she was your own daughter, sister, wife, friend, etc. 

In my past personal experiences working for someone else, the more they treated me like a human, with kindness and understanding, the more I respected and desired to please my employer. 

It‚Äôs sad, but most leaders don‚Äôt get this. Men, in particular. 

Demonstrating kindness, empathy, or compassion when communicating is not a sign of weakness. **You can be a strong leader while still being kind.

Obviously, when an employee takes advantage of the employer‚Äôs kindness or empathy, that is an issue. The employer

POST: So, a crane fell on my building during Hurricane Milton and the fire sprinklers went off, apparently for many hours. Most of my electronic equipment and anything cloth or particle board is destroyed. Looks like this is me giving up on the brick and mortar side of the business. I will let the lawyers do their lawyer thing to get me out of this lease. I need to know specifically where in PCOS I remove my brick and mortar practice location and add "mobile" instead. Maybe I'm just exhausted but I'm not finding that in the tutorials. Thank you for your assistance.

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôm so sorry

COMMENT 2: I‚Äôm so sorry you are going thru this!  I heard a crane fell up there. POST: Not having the bad doesn't make you good... 

I've had several times over the past couple weeks where I've been on calls with people interested in starting a business and they say something to the effect of, "I just want to get away from the crappy way healthcare is run." 

I get it. I've been there and have had some really bad experiences in healthcare and in jobs in the past. 

But just moving away from the bad and not being like them only goes so far. 

Each time I've asked, "what do you want your business to look like, what's the GOOD you're going to bring?" and each time the person couldn't answer it. 

Absolutely move away from the bad in healthcare but don't start there. Fill your business with things that are inspiring, hope providing, excellent, client focused, etc.

POST: Motivating post‚Ä¶ Was contacted by patient‚Äôs family member who is looking to hire a private practice PT. After talking with her, it became apparent she actually was never taught foundational knowledge of caring from a functional mobility standpoint (She had an extensive exercise packet that included ankle pumps, though). They owned equipment, hired caregivers, had two other family members and patient was being seen by home health intermittently previously. When I went over and met them, I was able to teach them how to do a two person transfer of the patient safely with a slide board from the hospital bed to their custom wheelchair. First time up in it in a year. It opened the world to them to know that they would be able to take her outside, tilt her back or do her hair, and it was really more about their piece of mine as well as the parent. In case you need to know why it‚Äôs so important that you all open good common sense, clinical practices, this is why! If there is anyone in the Fremont California area available to take on a lower level patient, DM me.

POST: I have owned my own LLC since February and am currently still working part time at an OP clinic. At the OP clinic, we do not have a receptionist and it falls on the therapists to answer phones, schedule patients, do patient intake, open up the clinic, etc. Since opening my own business and reducing my hours, my boss has been criticizing me for clocking in 10-15 minutes early to do the tasks above. My thinking is that this is the cost of not having a receptionist and I can‚Äôt be expected to do these tasks for free. Any insight would be appreciated!

COMMENT 1: I think your boss needs to consider who is supposed to be paid to open the clinic 15 min early so clients dont' arrive to a locked door. If they want someone else to do it they can schedule them and let you know that you shouldn't. If they want you to do it, you can't legally work off the clock.

COMMENT 2: I totally agree you should be paid for those extra tasks. I would have a convo with the boss and say you wouldn‚Äôt mind helping out but will be paid for that time or else you will be arriving right as the session starts and leaving we soon as it is over.

POST: Hey I would really like all of your opinions!  I am hearing up to open a brick and mortar location, with PT and sime other services.  There is a location that I am looking at in a small shopping center.  Price is good, but not really a desirable center with a 7/11 and a few other shops.  On the other hand it is very centrally located in the middle of tons of housing, next to my kids school, next to a park where all the kids play baseball and soccer.  Do you think location and reputation will make people look past the rest of the shopping center?  All advice is appreciated!

COMMENT 1: Ask the other tenants how they like being there‚Ä¶. And what their interaction with the landlord has been. Consider also how safe you feel coming and going there by yourself at night. Also look closely at parking. Very closely. That can be a big deal breaker for patients if the parking is sparse, or they have to walk far to get to your suite.

COMMENT 2: Always remember. Location. Location. Location. Would you be going there or your kids? Parents if you will have therapy?

POST: For those who run their PT practices out of other businesses like gyms, wellness facilities, chiropractic offices, etc,. what should I expect to pay to rent or lease space on a monthly basis? This would be very part time to begin - less than 15 hours per week. I know this will vary by location, but wanting some averages to go off of for negotiations.

Edited to add: this will be in the Midwest near Kansas City, MO. And a shared space not my own.

COMMENT 1: RE is so location dependent that your best bet is to find out the local per sq foot rate is and go from there.

COMMENT 2: Another thing to consider is will the space be completely yours? So can you leave marketing materials up in the common area even when you are not there? Or is it a shared space that you will only be renting hourly/as needed? 

I recommend trying to negotiate an hourly rate or fixed lease amount instead of paying a percent of what you are making‚Ä¶ the country club I rent from wanted me to do 70/30 with them but I asked for a fixed amount and they agreed to $650/month. I‚Äôm in California so this was very reasonable. I‚Äôm now making 8-10k a month so I definitely got the better end of the deal by not agreeing

POST: Mobile PT providers: For Part B MCR do they HAVE to be seen in their home location or can they be seen for services at a location of their choice? For instance a gym they belong to, another location other than their specific home if their home isn't conducive for PT and they want to use you as their PT and not go to an actual Clinic, etc....

COMMENT 1: They must be seen in their home for Medicare to cover the service.

COMMENT 2: Has to be their home or a clinic for Medicare to cover it.

Anywhere else is not a covered service. (Meaning you can charge your cash rate.)

POST: Help! I am starting a mobile side business in CA. I just opened an S-Corp as we can‚Äôt do an LLC here. When meeting with my accountant for personal taxes he told me it was crazy to open an S-Corp prior to having 60/80 K in profit and I should just be a sole proprietor. He recommends that I un-incorporate as s-corps are extra steps and expensive in CA. I did the s-corp so my personal assets are protected but he insisted that a good insurance would cover that. This is against any and all recommendations that I have received. Any thoughts/recs??? I am so irritated about the prospect of starting the process over as I am just about ready to start accepting clients! Thank you in advance.

COMMENT 1: Regardless of what your CPA says, you as a PT can establish ONLY an S-Corp in CA. The CPA may not be aware of that

COMMENT 2: I actually don't think any of the below answers are correct. You don't HAVE to be an s-corp because s-corp is a tax designation entity. It has nothing to do with the structure of your business. Physical Therapy practices cannot be LLCs in California but individuals can elect to be either a sole proprietor or professional corporation. All professional corporations

POST: This is for all the newbies who are struggling/doubting themselves.

Valuable lesson learned from flag football:
My 9yo is on a flag football team, and he's the youngest and the smallest kid on the team.  He's also one of the fastest and has a ridiculously good throwing arm with great accuracy.  Unfortunately, his coaches won't give him a chance at QB because of his size, and the kid they play at QB isn't accurate enough to throw long passes.  Last game, I watched my son start to give up.  He was sitting on the sideline with tears in his eyes, trying not to cry and visibly sinking in to sadness.  He was avoiding looking at me so that he didn't melt completely in to tears, but at one point he glanced at me and I mouthed "it's ok" and pointed at my heart and back at him.  His coach I think noticed his change in temperment, too, and a few minutes later he was put in on defense.  I can only assume that he was told to rush the quarterback, because as soon as the ball was snapped my son forced him back 10 yards.  The next play, he did it again.  And his entire body changed after that.  He held his head up, he smiled, he started enjoying it again.
After the game, I pulled him aside

POST: Times have changed significantly since 2016‚Ä¶

I remember buying an ebook titled ‚Äú12 things to do to start your practice‚Äù for $50 because I couldn‚Äôt find much information online about what to do. It was similar in nature to the free 10 step checklist we give out in this group, but that‚Äôs all there was at the time ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Now, fast forward to 2023, and we have more information than we know what to do with at our fingertips!

This is GREAT, but it also presents a new problem: information overload. 

Information overload can be paralyzing, in fact, it actually inhibits us in most cases from taking action.

Last year, we saw this problem growing and growing, and decided to launch Uncaged Bootcamp ü•æ. 

We saw the problem of a) new practice owners needed access to the RIGHT information, b) new practice owners needed access to the RIGHT AMOUNT of information, and c) new practice owners needed it at a price that they could afford to get the information and guidance they need.

That‚Äôs why we launched Bootcamp. 

And the first one of the year is kicking off on Tuesday, January 24th!

Myself, Kevin DeGroot, and David Bayl

POST: I have a tax question. I have an LLC. I was told to file as an S-corp to maximize the tax benefit. Does anyone have any insight on this issue?

COMMENT 1: Just met with accountant and learned a lot about this. Kicker is you must do payroll and have to pay yourself a ‚Äúreasonable wage‚Äù. have to be much more tedious with book-keeping. If you file as S-corp, can‚Äôt go ‚Äúbackwards‚Äù to LLC but as LLC you can change to S-corp at anytime. As a newbie, I‚Äôm gonna stay LLC to keep it simple but if I ever have employees, will likely change to S-corp.

POST: Distraction- the first of the great killers of your business. 

There's an amazing phenomenon that happens as you start to see opportunity around you. Similar to how you start to see the car you want to buy all over, opportunity starts to show up all over the place as well. 

As a staff PT, there's no reason to see opportunity so we often close off our minds to the possibility that there are opportunities outside the traditional staff PT position. 

More and more people are starting to see that this isn't the only option and that they can become "UNCAGED." Then they start a practice and hear all the different things that everyone in this and other groups are doing and there's a level of FOMO that happens that makes us think that we need to pursue every opportunity around us. 

One of the most important things that you can do as a business owner is figure out what's working, find the opportunity (not generally the opportunities) that you want to pursue and then focus and be engaged in that and not let yourself get distracted. 

People often think coaching is only for people who need help figuring out opportunities and strategy but one of the less valued but extremely important

POST: Don't know who needs to hear this but as a reminder, your business should work for you not the other way around. 

We use the wrong metrics to determine whether we're  successful. revenue each month, new clients, profit, etc. 

These are all focused on the business as the primary focus for growth and success as opposed to the business owner and members of the organization as the primary focus. 

I believe that most KPIs are helpful and obviously you need to have an understanding of them to know if your business is actually sustainable financially but if we're stopping here we fail to recognize what matters the most. 

Let's see some focus on KPIs of personal growth, health, lack of anxiety, peace of mind, and general joy and fulfillment in our businesses.

COMMENT 1: So true Kevin! Since starting my own business this year I have been able to focus on my own health and stress levels. I have dropped 35# so far and my goal for the calendar year is 50#. Plan on crushing that! Hitting my Kory Personal Indicators- the new KPI üòÑ

POST: We need to take into account that great achievement involves great risk.

It pains me to see so many people with such incredible dreams ‚Äî impactful, game-changing, earth-shattering dreams ‚Äî then to see that there is an unwillingness to take ANY risk to go after that dream. 

It breaks my heart. Because those dreams‚Ä¶where did they come from? What if that is your true calling in life?

What pains me is people who are not willing to take the risk but then you ARE willing to spend everyday questioning whether or not you are actually living up to your full potential. That‚Äôs not living, that‚Äôs living in agony. 

Our callings don‚Äôt leave us. They will always stay at our proverbial ‚Äúhouse‚Äù, and continue to knock at the door just waiting to be let in.

Some of us aren‚Äôt even willing to open the door. To take a risk in any way. But we all know deep down inside that the only way to make that dream happen is by taking a risk and believing in yourself. 

Open the door. üö™

POST: Has anyone gone from cash-based to in-network? I love my clinic and what we do‚Ä¶ but since I hired another therapist I can‚Äôt get enough clientele to make overhead. But then if I switch I feel like I‚Äôm going to end  up like every other mill in my town and I refuse to do that.  But I know others in here do insurance‚Ä¶. I saw my bosses in my old jobs rolling in dough while I was barely make ends meet‚Ä¶. How does insurance reimburse these days?  I have someone trying to convince me to be a multi-specialty clinic because it reimburses more‚Ä¶ is that true? Has anyone done this?

COMMENT 1: I see this a lot, so I‚Äôll be direct but hopefully helpful.

Most of the time the issue isn‚Äôt cash vs insurance. It‚Äôs that cash practices expect being cash + good clinical care to magically solve hiring and filling schedules. That works when you‚Äôre solo. It breaks the second you hire.

When you were alone, you had low overhead and lots of time. You could network, run workshops, meet people, hustle. Your hire is not going to do that at the same level, and they shouldn‚Äôt be expected to. At that point, you need real systems.

Cash pay clinics that scale well all have a few things in place:
‚Ä¢ Strong sales

POST: Explain to me like I‚Äôm a PT toddler‚Ä¶in a Cash Based Wellness setting can Medicare patients cash pay? How do I document  to reflect Wellness only?

COMMENT 1: I feel like everyone is over complicating this. The OP said cash based welless practice....

It depends on what services you are offering this person in your "cash based wellness setting". If it is truly a service like personal training or fitness related and doesn't fall under physical therapy, then absolutely you can accept cash. 

Now you can't just rename it wellness if it truly is a physical therapy service, that requires the care of a physical therapist and you are treating a specific diagnosis.

But if they're seeing you just simply to get stronger, get in better shape, lose weight, etc and it doesn't fall under physical therapy, you can charge cash.

I hope that helps a bit!

COMMENT 2: ‚ÄúPatient is able to perform independent ADLs and self care, but is seeking additional interventions to improve tolerance and skill for recreational activities‚Äù 

Can really write whatever you want. Have a justifiable reason and get an ABN and you‚Äôre fine. Medicare is not going to come after you for saving them money, you‚Äôre just j

COMMENT 1: You should have a fee schedule for what you charge per unit for each CPT codes. The amount they pay would be based upon your fee schedule and the units billed.

POST: Is anyone willing to share their single visit rate vs package rate and how they went about deciding if packages were a good idea?   Currently I don‚Äôt offer packages but considering it as a way to offer a more affordable option to those who need it.   Thank you!

COMMENT 1: I did primarily packages for about a year and now have switched to $150/session. Honestly has just been better all around with everyone paying the same rate and losing less in discounts all over the place. I do offer paid in full options for anyone who wants nothing to do with Superbills/insurance and just wants to pay in full for 12 sessions. Those are 10% off but I rarely use those now

COMMENT 2: The rates people are sharing will fluctuate depending on location, specialty, and if mobile/concierge. Consider a sales tactic called price anchoring where you have a significantly higher single session rate and packages that seem like a great discount. This pushes people to get the package, which leads to more money upfront and commitment from the patient's end to complete the POC. Individual sessions can lead to drop off/no show when the patient stops seeing the value or if there isnt an immediate change

POST: For those who are doing mobile PT and/or pelvic health PT and have hired other PTs, how/what do you pay your therapists? Hourly/salary/rate? 
(In Texas)

COMMENT 1: I hired a pelvic floor PT (in my brick and mortar clinic) and she has a commission rate - so base pay is one rate and that‚Äôs for any non-patient / non-revenue time like consults, documentation, marketing etc and then she gets a commission rate per service for times when she‚Äôs bringing in revenue (evals, treatment sessions). 

I consulted with an employment attorney to make sure that was legal and allowed, and my employee and I agreed on a base rate. 

So for instance, if she works an 8 hour day I pay her 8 hours at the base rate and if she sees 6 patients that day she gets $xx per patient x 6 extra for that day. She earns more when she does patient care, which is what I hired her for. I own a 100% cash based practice, for reference. This gives her more incentive and accountability for converting patients to evals and full POCs - which helps me avoid burn out from having so much pressure to fill her schedule - we both benefit when she‚Äôs fully booked üåüüåü

*also want to note that I‚Äôm hiring again so if anyone in Color

POST: Just listened to a podcast about a pool company who added a payment calculator to their website and their inbound leads went up by 200%. What do we think about adding a payment calculator to a website for cash pt?

COMMENT 1: I think the main factor to consider here is that:

People WANT pools. Pools are aspirational in that they‚Äôre a status symbol, provide excitement and entertainment, and can be seen as raising the value of a home potentially.

Sadly, no one WANTS physical therapy. And honestly it would be weird for someone to want physical therapy (in the traditional sense of getting rehab for an injury).

Classic cost vs investment scenario. PT is seen as a cost whereas a pool is seen as an investment.

POST: What is your favorite tactic for increasing prices? some are on a package and others are pay per visit and others are continued per visit at the package price discounted rate for a coke more follow ups - what do you tell them? My brains too tired to find the right words.

COMMENT 1: I recommend personally telling your current clients face to face. Offer them the opportunity to purchase more sessions at their current rate, or give them a heads up on when you‚Äôll be raising the price. Treat them like VIP. Then send an email to your list - give them a chance to buy at ur old rate (if ur looking for a cash injection) and then start charging to new patients (who will be the first to pay the new price).

You don‚Äôt have to tell them why. In fact don‚Äôt justify. Just say you have a price increase. They don‚Äôt need to know the details.

Start AUG 1....     

And tell current clients prices are going up, yet you value them so much and as a thank you you will keep them on the original price 

WIN - WIN

Good luck

POST: Hi everyone, 
I'm an OT who is planning on doing cash pay only on the side. Couple questions.
-Am I good to call it wellness services and see patients without a referral? 
-Am I in violation of any laws by doing so?
-OT is not direct access but does that matter if I'm not providing OT but am instead providing wellness?

COMMENT 1: What kind of services are you going to provide?

COMMENT 2: Do yourself a favor and review your practice act and ch 15 of Medicare benefits manual, so you have a clear understanding of the rules. You cannot have Medicare patients private pay for services that that would be considered skilled and medically necessary.  There are also the maintenance therapy rules which again, need to be skilled and medically necessary, but generally is not on a consistent basis unless you have a complex case and can justify the ongoing need for skilled care. Self pay for Medicare patients would be only for services not covered by Medicare.

POST: What‚Äôs the going rate for cash based pelvic PT in Los Angeles? Someone I know is being charged $250 per visit. Is that reasonable?

COMMENT 1: The only person who can deem it reasonable or not is the patient/client. Does he/she feel that what they are receiving is worth the rate they're paying? Because we all value things differently, and see that value from different points of view.

My rates are well above the rates of anyone else in my area. But every one of my clients are convinced that what they receive is well worth every penny they spent. Does the fact that my rates are higher than anyone else around me mean that my rates are unreasonable? People who choose not to work with me probably think so. People who do choose to work with me often feel I am undervaluing my services. The eye of the beholder is a powerful thing.

COMMENT 2: That‚Äôs within average rates for pelvic PTs in this area. But I also think this post has an undertone of judgment about someone else‚Äôs rates. As Joe said above, the only person who can deem it reasonable is the patient/client. If they feel the service is valuable at that rate, they will pay it. If they don‚Äôt, they won‚Äôt. COMMENT 1: Tell them you can‚Äôt do a percentage or fee per client with them because of anti-kickback laws that could make it seem like they are referring people to you just to increase their profit rather than for the benefit of the client.

POST: I approached a community center to use a portion of their pool to see patients for aquatic therapy. They are asking for 30% of revenue.
1) is this legal in healthcare, to pay a portion of revenue, especially if any of their members were to come to me for treatment?
2) is it just me or is 30% ridiculously high?

COMMENT 1: 30% is fairly standard. 20-40% is normal range, but can go to 50/50 even depending on what's included etc.

COMMENT 2: It can depend on your state. In some places it's not legal for them to charge you more than what would be considered a reasonable lease rate, in those states a percentage could get the facility in trouble. Some places charge providers a flat fee per hour with a monthly capped charge.

POST: Hello üôÇ 

I put together a checklist of things that I would consider paramount to include in any rehab, wellness or recovery plan 

1. Are you hitting the physical activity guidelines (2+ days per week of muscle strengthening activity and 75-150per week of vigorous aerobic activity)
2. Are you sleeping 7-9 hours a night?
3. Are you hitting your recommended protein target (1.6g/kg body weight)? 
4. Are you hitting your daily fiber goal (25-30g)
5. Are you getting >5 servings fruit and veg per day?

I see a lot of talks in here about what to charge for dry needling only sessions, how much a red light therapy coffin costs or what frequency vibrations should be in the vibration stimulation room. Are these the most health promoting things we can be spending time and money on? 

If your patients don‚Äôt hit these markers, is there a push by you to achieve them? If not, why? 

Finally, are you hitting these markers yourself?

POST: When applying for a new job, can the new employer see or have access to previous salary. I‚Äôm leaving my current employer to go to a clinic where in my interview they mentioned I would qualify for up to $15 per hour more. Ôøº

COMMENT 1: They can call your old employer and ask for salary, but they may not do that, and your old employer may not give them the information even if they ask.  That would be the only way for them to get that info.  There are a lot of "what if's" in that scenario.

But my question is-- why do you care if they know?  It's irrelavent what you made before.  If the new employer is offering to pay more, and/or your old employer was underpaying you, that's obviously why you want to leave (and a very good reason to leave at that).  The only numbers that are important here are the standard/average pay for a therapist with your education and experience in your area, and the cost of living in your area.  Demand what you're worth, and don't let them dictate that to you!

COMMENT 2: tell them you were making $150/hr

POST: I am contemplating adding a subscription type service for PT.  A monthly fee.  I am wondering if anyone here had successfully done something like this?  

I starting completely mobile, but am now hybrid.  I want to grow my in person/clinic visits and hoping to add some value by doing this.  

Any insight from someone who has done thus would be appreciated.

COMMENT 1: The concept works. It makes it easier from a billing standpoint. Allows for less administrative work. 

Your best bet is to limit how many visits per month. Plus you need a certain number of people ready to sign up. 

Say you only have 15 people the first 6 months that have subscriptions. If you're charging $200 to $250 per month, you're only bringing in $3000 to $3750. It would seem like charging more would be the thing, but people are already paying monthly for health insurance. If you're in a more affluent location, this may be fine. So location/population are key factors. Also having enough people that want to sign up for it. 

Subscription models for PT aren't common and it may take more convincing for others to join.

Pairing up with organizations/clinics that do concierge model of Healthcare is important.

POST: Hi all! Do superbills need to be broken down by cost per CPT code or is the total charge of all CPT codes sufficient? Example (for simple math) 
Option 1:
2 units 97110 = $50
2 units 97112 = $50 
total = $100

Option 2 (can it just be listed?) 
2 units 97110
2 units 97112
total = $100

COMMENT 1: Your CPT codes do not need to equal the cost off the visit. You can charge $70 per CPT code and cahrge a flat fee of $150. Insurance will reimbure the patient based on $150 but the data will be input for CPT codes in your area at $70 per unit

COMMENT 2: I've heard of people charging a certain rate per unit that will equal higher than the cash pay rate, then adding another line item to bring the rate down to the cash pay rate. IE if your cash pay rate was $250...
 1 unit Therex $100
1 unit manual $100
1 unit therapy $100
Provider Discount -$50.

POST: How to properly set your ‚Äúcash‚Äù price to reach your practice goals!

This was a comment made on a post that seemed to be helpful to others so I will share in more detail here:

I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs helpful to set your price based on competition in the area, I think it makes a lot more sense to set your price based on the goals you have for yourself individually and in the practice. 

So, let‚Äôs look at this together:

Step 1: What so you want to bring home per year after taxes? 

In this example I will use $100,000 (that‚Äôs take home after taxes, that would be pretty awesome right?! Well, it‚Äôs totally possible, let‚Äôs keep going‚Ä¶)

Step 2: Figure out how much you would need to bring in TOTAL (gross revenue for the year) using this calculation:

7/10   $100,000/x (picture below)

Example: $142,857

Step 3: Divide by 48 weeks (because you should absolutely be taking 4 weeks off per year as a business owner to make this thing sustainable üëäüèª)

Example= $2,976 per week

Step 4: What is your ‚Äúsweet spot‚Äù for number of visits per week that you could maintain as a solo preneur (for now, until you hire if that‚Äôs a goal of yours)

Example= $2976/18 visits per week

= $165/visit

So, that me

POST: I know PTs can‚Äôt order X-rays and have them reimbursed for insurance, but is there anything that says we can‚Äôt own X-ray machines and charge cash?

I've told people to go to urgent care over fractured collar bones (which are 99%+ non-op) and everyone still insists on going to the ED even though collar bone fractures are not life threatening. So imagin is a moot point. PTs no matter what will always be one of the last places people to go for a radiograph. While we can manage a lot of injuries, splinting and casting is not in this tool kit and the patient still needs to be referred out. (knowing what you don't know and when to refer in itself is a sign of expertise). If you're looking to push for added income, there are better places to look. The cost of a machine vs return on investment seems like we'd have to do multiple unnecessary images to even break even. Not to mention the unnecessary radiation this exposes patients and staff to. Also, our profession needs to focus on the issues that already exist lik

POST: ‚ÄúHow much should I pay my employees?‚Äù

This is always a question that I‚Äôm fascinated by the answers people respond with. 

Without outright saying it the general consensus is to pay what you can get away with. To squeeze profits out of employees. 

If you‚Äôre a business owner, how‚Äôd that work out for you when you were working for someone else? They squeezed you for as much profit as they could get and you felt burnt out, frustrated, taken advantage of, disrespected and more.

And that‚Äôs the answer that we‚Äôre going to go with when we run a business? To take advantage of the next generation of therapists who don‚Äôt know better?

I just heard a quote that trauma that‚Äôs unhealed is repeated. Let‚Äôs be a part of breaking the cycle not repeating it.

COMMENT 1: All of this is true. You need to pay them their worth and you also need to make sure you‚Äôre making at least 20-25% profit. You can‚Äôt just look at reimbursement related to pay to your contractor. As a business owner, you have other overhead to consider: EMR, rent, supplies and most importantly, risk. Be fair to them and be fair to yourself. A business that breaks even is not a business.

COMMENT 2: Good discussion point and very

POST: Help needed:

I have a cash based business where I specialize working with runners and triathletes. I do a lot of wellness visits /running evaluations. I had someone reach out to me who lives over an hour away and asked if I have a surcharge fee for going that far and I wanted to get everybody‚Äôs opinion on how much you‚Äôd recommend charging. With gas being so expensive and extra time driving that far wanted to be fair. I charge $130 for a basic evaluation and typically $150 for a separate running evaluation with fully analysis. 

Thank you!

COMMENT 1: $130-150/hr normal rate 

Driving to/from will be two hours of your time not including business expense of mileage on vehicle and gas. 

Definitely charge for time and expenses. 

Something like 20% of normal service charge for out of radius visits plus $.05/mile?

Or just a flat rate that changes with the market if you want simplicity

COMMENT 2: I wouldn't charge extra. Think of it as an extra marketing and extra word of mouth. Another person changed. Good luck my friend!

POST: A friend posted this today in our Leaders Network & I loved it *

You graduate college with 100k in debt, people clap and cheer for you. 

You get married and spend between 5-50k for one day, people will clap and cheer for you.

You take a 200k loan from the bank to buy your first house, people will clap and cheer for you. 

You take a loan for 30 - 40k for a car (a depreciating asset) with an interest rate, people will clap and cheer for you. 

Thats 500,000 in total debt that MOST people are living in, and somehow they are feeling good about it because people are congratulating them for it. 

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

‚ÄúCan you get your money back?‚Äù

To my fellow entrepreneurs, STOP WORRYING ABOUT WHAT OTHERS THINK AND KEEP PROMOTING YOUR BUS

POST: Is it possible to sell your hybrid practice if you are the only clinician, a 3 year old clinic with 100+ google reivews a good profit margin and revenue of 15-18k a month in a growing city and building is in s good location

COMMENT 1: My understanding is that a business is more attractive when the money coming in has nothing to do with you (e.g. others generate your revenue). The buyer tends not to care about things like Google reviews, novelty of practice, etc., they just care about the EBITDA. Even after selling, the buyer will likely expect you to be part of the practice for 18+ months to transition and get established. That's just based on one conversation I had with a broker. My practice has several employees, so maybe it's different for a solo practice.

COMMENT 2: At one point I was just curious what my business was worth so I had someone that buys similar businesses look at mine. The #1 thing they said is, can the business survive if me/the owner wasn't around and is the brand recognition solely built around me. If it relies heavily on the owner, there is much less value then a practice with other therapists. Having contracts with referral partners helps build value

POST: "I lost 10 pounds in a week! Looking to lose weight before the holidays? Message me "fit for the holidays" and I'll give you information."

Does this type of hook (attractive statement) sound familiar? We've all seen it. I've done something remarkable and want to share with others how they too can have the unprecedented success they've had. 

Does it seem too good to be true? 

Does it make sense to lose 10# in a week? Is that healthy? 

We want your business to grow and we want you to do it in as healthy a way as possible.

Fast growth can happen. We've had seasons of ridiculous growth in the past and some has been healthy but a lot of our fast growth hasn't been that healthy. 

It's not sexy to tell people to grow in a healthy way but that's what we're going to continue shouting from the rooftops.

POST: üó£Ô∏èA MESSAGE‚ÄºÔ∏è

A violinist played for 45 minutes in the New York subway.  A handful of people stopped, a couple clapped, and the violinist raised about $30 in tips. 

No one knew this, but the violinist was Joshua Bell, one of the best musicians in the world. In that subway, Joshua played one of the most intricate pieces ever written with a violin worth 3.5 million dollars.

Two days before he played in the subway, Joshua Bell sold out a Boston theatre, and the seats averaged about $100. 

The experiment proved that the extraordinary in an ordinary environment does not shine and is so often overlooked and undervalued.

There are brilliantly talented people everywhere who aren‚Äôt receiving the recognition and reward they deserve. But once they arm themselves with value and confidence and remove themselves from an environment that isn‚Äôt serving them, they thrive and grow. 

Your gut is telling you something. Listen to it if it‚Äôs telling you where you are isn‚Äôt enough! 

Go where you are appreciated and valued. 

Know Your Worth.

@shaynevibes_truth

POST: For PTs billing out of network how much have you seen in reimbursement for 4 units of physical therapy?

COMMENT 1: All you have to do is submit a claim and see. Your patient won't be meeting their OON deductible anytime soon so you will have plenty of data on what the plan pays. All of them pay differently OON even within the same carrier. Some plans pay dollar for dollar and some pay a % above Medicare. If you are billing OON you need to be collecting your cash pay rate and by the time you might get reimbursed you will know what the plan pays.

COMMENT 2: Completely depends on the plan/carrier. Sometimes $80, sometimes $500 like stated above. 

We balance bill and always collect up to our cash rate if insurance low balls us. We disclose this ahead of time and it‚Äôs very legal to do so. Their EOBs even say it to the patient that the provider is OON and may charge higher than what the EOB says.

POST: This is an official Medicare government test you must take to sell Medicare advantage plans   Read that and tell me if it makes any sense üëÄ keep in mind. This is a 2026 test because open enrollment starts this week.

COMMENT 2: Its the basis of how medicare works and advantage plans follow the guildelines they just "manage" it a lot more. Medicare A/"advantage" A allows for up to 100 days of consecutive services (typically paid at days 1-20 100%, then often 80% after. If all consecutive services are used the patient has 60 days were they must remain out of the hospital to reset med A benefits. Although i did have one patient that exhausted his lifetime medicare A benefits which is wild. Med B benefits never really go out. Where these "advantage plans" screw you though is they really like to dictate how much therapy theyre willing to give under both a & b and it has to often be pre-authorized and sometimes they even dictate wh

These PPOs often have a large deductible or out of pocket max that the patient has to meet prior to insurance ‚Äúkicking in‚Äù for services. You are allowed to have these patients private pay since it‚Äôs not a traditional Medicare plan (sometimes they‚Äôre more willing to go this route if you can provide them with a superbill so they can submit it to insurance themselves). POST: Did you think the Hertel and Brown case was a fluke or a "one off"? Guess again!

Owner of Oahu Physical Therapy Clinic Sentenced to 9 Months in Federal Prison for Health Care Fraud.

Timothy Wells admitted that from July 2013 through early 2020, he submitted false claims for payment for physical therapy services to TRICARE and Medicare. Wells used individuals not trained in physical therapy, including massage therapists, athletic trainers, personal trainers, and an individual who had no professional licenses or certifications whatsoever, to provide physical therapy services to patients. Wells admitted that he knew these individuals were not authorized providers and that he could not legitimately bill TRICARE and Medicare for physical therapy services rendered by them, even under supervision. Nevertheless, Wells billed the programs as though the services had been provided by licensed practitioners.

COMMENT 1: I just don‚Äôt understand all the hard work and effort it takes to become a therapist and people choose greed over integrity it‚Äôs just crazy üíÄ

POST: So for all those that think PTs, PTAs, OTs, OTAs, and billers do not go to jail and that it must be okay because we got paid and everyone does it, you might want to google search Hertel and Brown case. 20 therapists, assistants, and billers indicted plus the company. 17 of the PTs, PTAs, and billers, including the 2 owners, have now pled guilty to a felony count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and health care fraud.

The 2 owners will receive a 6-year prison sentence in federal prison followed by 3 years of supervised release. Essentially, their careers are over. Other 15 have sentences scheduled in May, June, and July.

The other 3 have jury selection start tomorrow. 

This is why documentation, CPT coding, billing, etc., should be mandatory CEU requirements for all therapists and assistants.

COMMENT 1: So, they did things that we all know are wrong? Right?

POST: For those of you that are OON/cash and take Medicare part B. For me, Medicare patients pay well enough to make it worth being in network with them. You cannot have them sign an ABN as a blanket Coverage at the beginning of every treatment. You only have them sign an ABN when they are doing a treatment that you don‚Äôt expect to be covered like after the KX modifier. (I believe)
I like having a mixture of Medicare and cash pay.

POST: Hello. Now that I am credentialed with Medicare, will I need to be credentialed with each separate Medicare advantage plan such as Aetna Medicare in order to fully be paid?Thank you.

COMMENT 1: Hi. Crucial clarification here: Is the Aetna plan a supplemental? (I think it'll say so on their insurance card.)

You only ever need to be in network with the primary payer -- the primary payer will automatically send the remainder of the (approved) bill to the supplemental. You'll get a check in the mail from the supplemental later; timing varies. 

If the Aetna plan is their primary plan, then it's a Medicare replacement. Don't bother going in network with those, generally speaking, unless you have really good reasons. If their plan has OON benefits for PT, they reimburse at the same rates as Medicare would have. 

Please feel free to set up a call with me if you need more guidance -- since we've chatted about some of these things already.

COMMENT 2: understabd Medicare (dis)Advantage plans are NOT MEDICARE.  They are commercial insurance.  So if you are going to hassle with them then yes you will have to credential with each one.  Unless they have OON BENEFITS and you want to has

POST: Letter from Medicare stating we bill more  therex than our counterparts ....  I'm not sure what to think ...  what else are you to bill besides therex as a PT OT.... I could see if it was all Neuro or an Therapeutic activities that is billed higher .... 
...the letter stated for us to look into our billing practices in the next 6 months 

Thoughts on this ....

COMMENT 1: The best way to avoid audits is to diversify your billing.  Any exercise can be billed under any type of code, it all depends on why you‚Äôre doing an exercise.

Straight leg raise = ther act if you‚Äôre prescribing it to help the pt get their leg in bed 

SLR = neuro if regaining quad and hip flexor cocontraction. 

SLR = ther ex if doing it purely for strengthening. (Generally though, aren‚Äôt you strengthening something so the patient can DO things?) 

I bill ther ex the least because I‚Äôm usually prescribing an exercise to have the patient regain a specific task.  It also bills the least.

COMMENT 2: A lot of therex is them telling you that you aren't focusing enough on function, which is all that medicare wants to pay for

POST: So PT can‚Äôt accept cash from a Medicaid patient if they want more services but they can pay a diatician??    ü§°ü§°ü§°ü§°ü§°
Logic??

COMMENT 1: Stupid law, but the whole point of Medicaid is financial assistance. If they can afford to private pay for any clinician, they probably need to get off Medicaid. At least, that's how the government sees it. I know it's more complicated than that.

COMMENT 2: If  Medicare is primary insurance and Medicaid secondary, you can not balance bill the patient if you are not a Medicaid provider. You have to follow Medicare billing rules for non covered services (ABN, still bill MC, etc) if what you provide is not covered by MC.
However, if your patient is not Medicare recipient and has only Medicaid, then ability to charge cash for PT is state specific. I am in Florida.I called and emailed to the Florida Medicaid and was told that I can collect cash for PT services if I am not a Medicaid provider.

POST: Question: I am a contract employee for a Pediatric Outpatient clinic. They are encouraging us to "bill an extra unit," for certain insurance companies after client's deductibles have been met. COMMENT 1: ‚ÄúBilling an extra unit‚Äù wiithout an appropriate amount of extra billable time spent with the patient is fraud. Period.

Using your clinical judgement to see if they need more therapy is always a good idea. But just billing an extra unit and justifying it because the patient doesn‚Äôt pay is‚Ä¶ fraud.

COMMENT 2: In order to bill for the extra until you would need to treat the patient longer. If you treated for a longer duration then you should absolutely bill for that added unit. If not then you‚Äôre committing fraud

POST: UPDATE: 

Just found out the payer has been sending payment to another PT group because the practitioner‚Äôs NPI is associated with that group as well (she works there prn). Has anyone encountered this?  I am at a loss for how to fix this.  

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

POST: Taking part of my reply to someone else‚Äôs great question post. 
***
Why do people agree to pay cash to CAM specialists (Massage Therapists, Acupuncturists, Chiros, Personal Trainers) and Nutritionists and psychiatrists in Psychotherapists, yet fully expect insurance-based PT?

I think that the answer is somewhere in the following: 

PT as profession had a long journey to become recognized as a medical/healthcare field. Attaining medical recognition was a win and a loss. 

Today, two dfferent models of operation exist: 

Chiro + Personal Training + Massage = Wellness ~> Luxury: cash

PT = medical = necessity: insurance

Do we as PTs want to be associated with one or the other?

The answer is neither and both.
We need to carve a new model. And carving something new is‚Ä¶ hard.

Maybe the answer is to change the Wellness to Wellbeing in branding? Or Wellbeing and Whole Health?

Like .. ‚ÄúWellbeing in Function and Whole in Health PT?‚Äù

Dunno.

I am in the very beginning of thinking about my own practice, associated with an unexpected but a welcome move. 

I will be planning and carving, drafting and re-writing things. 

One thing that I will be doing from the very start is to brand

POST: Today my patient had a genius idea!!! Insurance companies give their patients a set amount (say 10) PT sessions each year. They can be for a problem or preventative like ergonomics!!! In the end they would pay less for meds and surgery!

COMMENT 1: One of the main reasons our healthcare system is as broke as it is is because of how frequently people change insurance providers. Because of this, insurance companies see preventative healthcare as lining the pockets of their competitors. 

To market this, you would want to pursue a large corporation (the pull with insurance companies) that has an abnormally low degree of employee turnover (benefit from keeping employees healthy).

COMMENT 2: There is a company named Centene. They actually bought a medium size company that specialized in doctor visits at home and used it to prevent hospitalizations and save money. A managed system like that would be the company to pitch it to.

POST: Will anyone share with me the form they give patients to sign if they have Medicare but are using you for cash pay? 
Thanks so much!
Edited to add: they already use medicare services but want extra hours of cash PT each week outside of their medicare services

COMMENT 1: You must bill Medicare for medically necessary skilled therapy services. Clients are not allowed to pay cash for these services. If they are received wellness services (be clear on how you define this) that are not covered by Medicare then there is no form that they need to sign.  If the services might normally be covered but do not meet the skilled therapy medically necessary code outlined in Section 220.2 of CMS Chapter 15 then  you will need to have the client sign an ABN. Here is the link to Chapter 15 https://www.cms.gov/Regulations-and-Guidance/Guidance/Manuals/downloads/bp102c15.pdf   Here is a link on how to correctly complete an ABN. https://www.cms.gov/Medicare/Medicare-General-Information/BNI/Downloads/ABN-Form-Instructions.pdf

COMMENT 2: Its a complete scam that medicare specificly names professions that can't opt out while saying others can for no reason at all. It's completely discriminatory an

POST: Where does medicare draw the line of 'medically necessary' (I know I'm not the first one to ask this....just frustrated again)?  Say we have someone who can perform their daily functions with no restrictions (but maybe some mild discomfort/pain), however their main complaint is that  they are limited & painful in their ability to go hiking and play pickleball.  Would a wellness plan, with a treatment focus around making hiking & pickleball easier for them to participate in,  even if it entailed some manual therapy skills, be allowed under a cash-pay arrangement?

COMMENT 1: Don‚Äôt confuse services covered under the Medicare benefit with medical necessity. 

Medical necessity is just one part of the requirements for covered services. 

Reasonable is another part. 

Standard of care is another part. 

This is a balancing act for sure. As Nancy mentioned, you are the therapist and make your determination based on the initial evaluation and findings. 

After that you develop your treatment plan and based on published guidelines you make a determination of what YOU believe falls within the coverage guidelines. 

You may charge cash for non-covered services and seek reimbursement fo

POST: And ‚Ä¶. Let‚Äôs hear what this means to you in relation to the ‚Äúevolution‚Äù of PT over the last ‚Ä¶50 years‚Ä¶. And GO!

COMMENT 1: That we (therapists) are no longer the ones who decide what a patient‚Äôs potential is and facilitate the realization of that potential. We now often give them treatment to address where they are and pass them to a different level of care. The result is that many patients don‚Äôt reach their full recovery potential. Bad for them. Bad for us.

COMMENT 2: Every new grad (and especially seasoned PTs who know better) who works for a ‚ÄúPT Mill‚Äù with unrealistic productivity demands is making it harder for all of us to push back against exploitation and protect the integrity of our profession.

Until we come together as a majority to refuse unreasonable conditions, nothing will change.

I left in network care years ago but it took years of building credibility and experience (and feeling the burnout) in network to make the leap.

COMMENT 1: Typically then you'd follow your state practice act. Always follow the strictest rule

COMMENT 2: Q: Checking insurance benefits and I always get confused when it says no referral required, and no visit limits. 
Can I see the patient without a doctor‚Äôs referral, no signed POC and however long the patient needs? 

No referral means it's not an HMO plan that would need a referral. 
Check your state direct access laws, we have 20 days or 10 visits whichever is sooner without a script, and a script from a doctor is needed to have the insurance pick it up. And also charts need a doctor's signed POC/eval and re-evals.

POST: Dear group, looking for a little advice here.  I've been in private practice PT for over 20 years in my area. POST: I despise marketing emails.  I hate getting them... they immediately get trashed.  But "everyone" says to build your email list and send out the emails routinely.  I read in a book recently that you should expect about a 1% conversion on emails if you're making an offer.  So, despite hating the very thing that I was advised to do, I created a flyer and sent out an email with an offer of 20% off multi-visit packages through the end of the year.

You guys.

I sent the email out FOUR days ago to about 180 people, and I've sold SEVEN packages since then - about half of those are routine clients who would've purchased packages anyway, but at least one person is someone who had been a client earlier in the year and the email kickstarted him to come back.

Moral of the story: send the email, make the offer!

POST: This is the message I got from my patient today after going to her ortho follow up with her. I‚Äôve heard Anthony Maritato talk about going to MD appts with patients several times. David Bayliff and I have been talking about how to network too! 

Since starting my mobile business I want to do things differently than I‚Äôve done in the past and try to add as much value as I can. 

She is my first patient. She is seeing a local ortho doc that I have met a few times and grew up with a ton of people I grew up with. 

She had a distal humerus fracture and wore her sling 4 weeks longer than she should have. She couldn‚Äôt get PT here because she had out of state BCBS. A friend of a friend gave her my number. 

When I first saw her, she was in tears after her ortho postop visit. They told her to do PT 4x/wk, get dynasplint and she would need about 4 months of PT to even hope of getting her range back. She‚Äôs 35 c 3 kids and was scared to death. 

I gave her my rate and we decided on once a week if she would do exactly what she was supposed to do. 

After week 3 we decided on the dynasplint. Yesterday was week 6 of PT at once a week and week 3 of the dynasplint. She maxed out the extension

POST: This post is for those who are nervous about networking with local businesses. I met with six different businesses over the last two weeks - two small gyms, a running shoe store, a massage therapist, and two Pilates studios. Of those six businesses and WITHOUT ME ASKING: 

- three offered to host a pop-up for me 
- one offered to host a workshop ‚Äúbecause I have so many clients I know will benefit from this‚Äù
- the shoe store wants me at local runs they organize as medical coverage ‚Äúand so you can get free advertising‚Äù
- one offered to rent me a room should I want a home base 
- two offered to feature my business as part of their monthly newsletters with their email lists
- one Pilates studio walked me down the street to introduce me to a local acupuncturist ‚Äúbecause they need to know about your business‚Äù 

Will all of these pan out perfectly? No. But people are far more encouraging than I anticipated. All I did was:

1. Tell these businesses that I want to know where to send my clients (so their biz will benefit from meeting with me)
2. Speak about how I want to fill a need in my community that other PT clinics don‚Äôt
3. I was honest in telling these businesses that I just star

POST: It seems like ‚Äúcoaching‚Äù is completely unregulated. Why should I continue to fight insurance companies on reimbursement for CPT codes and to network for referrals from MD‚Äôs who don‚Äôt really value what I do? I‚Äôm in one of the 3 states with no direct access for a PT. Why not just become a ‚Äúcoach‚Äù and ‚Äútrain‚Äù people with a rehab/therapy mindset? Essentially be strictly Wellness. Surely I can find a masseuse to work with to offer manual/soft tissue services.

COMMENT 1: It‚Äôs a tricky! I‚Äôm an OT in same place. I‚Äôm doing educational consulting/coaching for families but very low key. I want to expand but am worried

COMMENT 2: If I remember correctly there were some PTs in Texas that tried this. They were punished because they were held to the "limitations of their highest license". Essentially they were PTs with personal trainer Certs "training" people. They were in violation of direct access laws because the grey area was deemed to lean towards therapy and not wellness. So be careful with all your notes and wording you use. I'm not the extent of the punishment, but it was mentioned on a Jarod Carter podcast.

POST: Does anyone have recommendations/advice on how to do better marketing? Specifically via social media/Instagram to gain folllowers?  I now have online fitness programs up on Everfit app and trying to find ideas on how to better market the programs and gain clients.  Marketing to my womens mountain bike club of 3,500+ ladies hasn‚Äôt been enough so far.  üòí

COMMENT 1: Be consistent, pool your audience to know what they want to know, create content around what they want to know and not what you think they want to know, be consistent and post daily.

COMMENT 2: Don‚Äôt overcomplicate it. Just provide value. Post simple videos or text posts answering a common question or issue your clients run into. Do NOT get caught into the trap of trying over explain yourself in your caption (we all do it). Because then it will take you like 45 minutes to make 1 post. Keep things as simple as you can and try to make each post just 1 main thing you are trying to get across. Don‚Äôt worry about editing posts or anything. Just post. Show your personality (people work with people they like). See what works and what doesn‚Äôt. Go from there. 

Why would somebody want your program? What are they going to get

POST: "$500k/year" 

That's what someone just told me they had sitting there unbilled or clients that are being turned away because they can't find qualified therapists.  

First- it's amazing what our clients are accomplishing in their practices that this is what's waiting in referrals and being turned away. 

But more importantly than that, it gave me an opportunity to talk about something I've been noticing a lot recently. 

Many people and potential clients of Uncaged only want to talk about how to grow a business and how to make $$$$ in a practice. They LOVE talking about the ENGINE of a business but very rarely talk about the BRAKES of a business. 

Are brakes sexy? no. It's way cooler to talk about how many horsepower a car has 

But one of the quickest way to derail your practice/business is to sacrifice the quality of care, delivery, and boundaries. 

Don't build a business that is all horsepower and no stopping power.

POST: Big question for ones who are practice with a gym and is hybrid:

A new gym opened, offering a PT room to solely just one PT.  They‚Äôre charging a rate of $2,000/mo and do not take any percentages and have only on PT on site for the gym.

Still being a new practice and currently mobile, the gym itself is an ideal set-up, but I‚Äôm still trying to build clientele. I believe the gym is 18,000sq ft and trainers would refer their clients to me.

COMMENT 1: I have this exact set up. But in my opinion $2000 is way too high. I would try to negotiate a lesser amount. $1200 max. Or try to negotiate a cost per visit so the gym is incentivized to send you clients.

POST: What was your best marketing strategy to date? What has yielded the best return on investment?

Get super clear on who you‚Äôd like to serve and become the ‚Äúgo-to person‚Äù for that. Don‚Äôt spray and pray with your messaging. üòâ

1. Surface level
2. Deeper/intrinsic
3. Societal

1. Knee pain
2. Not being able to care for grandkids without pain
3. Growing older doesn‚Äôt mean you have to deal with pain and stop doing the things you love. 

(Just an ortho example of the levels) üòÅ

POST: I have an interesting case that I want some input on from you all. 

Client complains of pain around the R eye/forehead that happens when he does any type of physical activity or standing up from sitting that lasts 15-45 seconds intensity of 6-9/10 and then goes away to a 0/10. Symptoms are reproduced with resisted left cervical rotation and deep palpation to right upper trap and SCM. He had a nerve block to occipital nerve which seemed to improve his symptoms. MRI of brain negative. Tested for temporal arteritis was negative. Tested BP seated vs standing and all WNL. 

Dry needling to R UT and SCM reproduced his symptoms and then improved after being in for 2-15 min. I haven‚Äôt DN suboccipital region. But any type of cervical exertion causes the headaches. 

Any ideas from anyone?

COMMENT 1: How long has he had pain for?

COMMENT 2: If the occipital nerve block temporarily relieved his symptoms consider nerve entrapment.  If therapy can‚Äôt fix him I recommend Tim Tollestrup MD peripheral nerve surgeon.

*"God placed this mission in my heart."*

*"I do what I do because I see the potential in other people."*

*"To provide hope, because the world is filled with brokenness."*

*"To be a pillar of hope."*

*"To build something that serves the community and to move beyond myself."*

As Kevin DeGroot, Josh Payne, Kalyca Jin Zarich, and I have held board meetings with our mastermind students over the past two weeks, these are some of the amazing comments that these incredible people have stated when asked:

*Why do you do what you do?*

*Why is that important?*

We also ask them to rate how they are doing in the areas of the 5 F's:

*Faith *

*Family *

*Fitness *

*Finance *

*Fulfillment*

And what is interesting is that no one's level of fulfillment has been tied to their finance rating.

Perhaps because your business or your job should exist for you; not you existing for your job.

Maybe it is because, virtually, we have never had a student or prospective student tell us that they wanted to create their own practice in order to make more money.

Yes, making more money does happen to be a reason.  But it is never the first thing a person says.  It

POST: I like to send a handwritten thank you card to each MD that sends me referrals, every time they send me a new patient. Would you name the patient in the note? or just a generic "Thank you for the referral". Is anyone else doing this?

COMMENT 1: As a physician, I would like a "Thanks for referring (patient name). She is progressing well and I plan to see her for another x weeks. She has a followup set up to see you after that. Please don't hesitate to call us you have any questions about her therapy."

As all healthcare providers, physicians are busy. I dont want to spend the time opening a card that just says thanks for the referral. What does help is someone saying you passed the ball, I've got it and I'm taking care of the patient. It also helps that it's noted the patient has a followup already and it's not asking the physician to look things up or set more things up. Hope that helps. If it's ok with HIPPA (I would think it is) it helps to include the name because there are certain patients that stick out to you and having that reassurance in a quick read is gold.

COMMENT 2: If possible, I‚Äôll personally drop off the eval and offer an in-person thank you to any new MD ref

POST: I've seen a lot of concern about us losing the title "professional". The absolute lowest bar of acting like a professional is being a member of your professional organization. 

APTA is all over this fight and other fights like it every day, year after year. They protect and maintain our profession from constant attacks on our scope and our payment. I hope you'll join the 100,000 members of APTA who choose to support these constant battles that threaten our profession.
 

COMMENT 1: I'm going to step away from this and let it bubble a little bit, but I'll be back with more responses. I would love to hear more from others who have had positive experiences in APTA. I see your thumbs up, but we need more vocal advocacy like this for our essential organization. Most people don't understand what a professional organization does, and I'm happy to try to pull back the curtain. A lot fo the work sounds boring, but it is literally the difference between PT existing and being swallowed up bit-by-bit by "body workers" and others. We would cease to exist shockingly fast without APTA.

COMMENT 2: All the pitchforks and torches came out to represent here, and I can't possibly find the time

POST: What advice would you give to a therapist who wants to be uncaged?

COMMENT 1: Answer three questions: WHY and WHY and WHAT.... Why do you want to be UNCAGED for yourself? What is in it for you and your family (or future family).  WHY does YOUR practice have to exist in the community?  WHAT is it that you do for people. Then..... BELIEVE in yourself. Understand what your PASSION is. Display ACTIVE PATIENCE.  Maintain your GRIT.  Finally, truly, save yourself time, money (in the long run), and a world of frustration by having a guide/mentor/coach who has done it to lead you.

COMMENT 2: Hire a business coach.  They help rocket your business forward faster and with less guesswork.  They have several proven processes because they've been there and have already helped others.
You're going to make your own mistakes no matter what, but you can avoid the ones they've already made. They know how to coach past them. 
David Bayliff , who runs this page has an incredible program. Free knowledge is great, but it only takes you so far.
You need to invest in your knowledge by hiring a coach. 
I am in my 3rd practice. A formal coaching group was the best investment I ever made.

POST: I have a patient that requested medical records for disability. We provided these records and she wants to have a meeting to discuss some ‚Äúinaccuracies‚Äù she sees in the record. I have explained that we can not/will not change the documentation. Am I required to meet with her? Or can I just ask her to email me a list of things she disagrees with and attach them to her medical record so that her concerns are documented?

COMMENT 1: I believe a pt. Can request amendments for what they believe to be inaccuracies and you do have a certain time frame in which you need to respond. I would honestly call your malpractice and see what the procedure should be.

COMMENT 2: I recently reviewed some of my medical records and found inaccuracies.  They are entitled to request a change if they are inaccurate.

POST: PTs- thoughts on becoming an APTA member? I've heard mixed thoughts and wondering if it worth it. If so, what other dues (chapters) did feel was worth paying for in addition to membership and your state chapter?

COMMENT 1: I love being a member. I'm headed to Boston on Wednesday for Combined Section Meeting, a gathering of over 15,000 PTs/PTAs students. The educational content, resources, CEUs is top notch and being a member and getting involved in the Academy of APTA Home Health has introduced me to tons of clinicians across the country, given me opportunities to represent home/mobile based clinicians on CPG projects, present content on part B at home to the Neuro section. I could go on and on. It is a seriously small percentage of our profession that belong to the APTA compared to other health care professions. I encourage everyone to get involved and be the difference you want to see.

COMMENT 2: No way. My job paid all membership dues so I became a member and part of several sections and stayed a member for 6 years and got nothing out of it more than a magazine and the occasional sticker. Not worth it.

POST: ## Plans succeed with many advisors...

**Looking to have your plans succeed in 2024? **

**It would be wise to get around many advisors.**

Many advisory groups have been started by the APTA and other organizations, but to be honest, they seem to miss the mark of what a practice owner actually needs.

That is why we created Success Council's - A council of 6-8 practice owners across the country that are in similar revenue range and size to grow in connection and trust with. We say #ironsharpensiron, but the question is - Are you putting yourself around iron?

When you start to run a business, you start to quickly realize that the game that you are playing is vastly different than most people around you, and most of the time...family and friends simply can't relate.

This can be frustrating and isolating. We have created the community where you can grow your own personal board of directors as you grow your company. Other entrepreneurs that you can rely upon for counsel, accountability, collaboration, and support.

If you are interested, comment "Success Council" below! And then, we will get you all of the details.

COMMENT 1: Not only is this Community, it‚Äôs FAMILY üôåüôåüíØüíØ

POST: Hello!

I'd love your input. I launched my practice five months ago, but I'm struggling to gain traction. His fee is $750/month and he covers all the operational costs. I'm planning to collaborate for three months to assess the return on investment. Do you believe his services justify the cost? POST: MAJOR ANNOUNCEMENT. 

TLDR: register for the Uncaged Clinician Community and App launch party using the link in the comments! 

Honestly this is the biggest thing we've ever done at Uncaged Clinician and our team is so excited to start sharing it with you! 

We're in a unique position that we've been asked to leverage for the betterment of PTs, OTs, SLPs, Chiros, Mental Health Providers and more. At first, Josh Payne, David Bayliff and myself wanted to "stay in our lane" and focus on coaching and mentorship but this changes NOW. 

This group has evolved and grown through the last several years and although the growth is exciting, it's also very sad that the level of satisfaction and fulfillment in healthcare seems to be plummeting. 

We all have our thoughts on why this is the case but we're all fighting in isolation and lack a common voice and space for grassroots change and growth. 

Will we "fix" healthcare in the US? probably not, but the goal that we have is to unify the voices of PTs, OTs, SLPs, and more and stop the infighting that keeps us from collective growth. 

In order to bring us more together, we're launching a community platform and app that focuses on clinica

POST: This year has been very challenging for me‚Ä¶ 

Overwhelm‚Ä¶.
Underwhelm‚Ä¶
Frustration‚Ä¶
Boredom‚Ä¶.
Overwork‚Ä¶.
Underwork‚Ä¶
Underpay‚Ä¶.

All these emotions/ situations wrapped up in a single day, week, month and starting the year.  Getting away from my roots and proven known business concepts has left me paralyzed.  Speaking with my accountability partner these last few days has left me with the realization that I fill my days with tasks that don‚Äôt serve me, my family, my finances or my business. (Yes in that order). I feel busy, but what I am doing is holding space for tasks that won‚Äôt move me forward and missing opportunities that could‚Ä¶ self sabotage is real and this is my limiting belief‚Ä¶ ‚Äúbeing busy will get me to my goals‚Äù. I‚Äôve been lying to myself for the past 30-40 years and have limited myself dramatically.  This year will be different.  

I refuse to allow myself to be held back and kill my dreams‚Ä¶ I am working through my limiting beliefs and making changes to fix myself.  Saying no to things is the first thing I am changing. Let this year be YOUR year to make amazing changes so that all your dreams can come true and you can change your life.

POST: I needed to hear this because I have had these thoughts recently. Hope this helps some of you in the trenches with me. 

We all have bad days, weeks or months‚Ä¶. It is the nature of the beast of being a solopreneur and biz owner. Hell it‚Äôs the nature of life. But when is it good to give up??

I heard this from Jake Thompson today on one of his old podcasts.  ‚ÄúNever give up on a bad day. It‚Äôs easy to want to quit on our dreams and desires when we have a bad day, because everything in our perspective makes it seem like we should. But if you have a good day and you still want to quit, then maybe strongly consider it.‚Äù  If you can have a good day and you still don‚Äôt feel like this is for you, don‚Äôt feel bad. Realize that you have the gumption to look at yourself in the face and know that this road isn‚Äôt for you. And that‚Äôs ok. But don‚Äôt give up just because you had a rough/bad day. They are going to happen‚Ä¶

Uncaged clinicians, don‚Äôt give up on your dream because of a rough patch. We all have them, reach out and talk to someone: a mentor, accountability partner, a friend. They can help you through. If after a good day, you still want to quit, then realize this may not be for you,
