POST: ISOLATION: The second great killer of your business 

You weren't meant to do THIS alone and by "THIS" I don't just mean business. 

Scenario 1: I hate when people outside a select few friends ask me how business is going. It doesn't seem fair to have to communicate something as complicated as an entrepreneur's emotions. It's great, it's terrible, it's ok, it's frustrating, it's exhilarating, it's everything at the same time. So most of the time people ask I simply say "it's going well" and leave it at that. 

The problem with this? It puts you on an island feeling that no one can possibly understand or know what you're going through. 

Scenario 2: there's something that's been engrained in you from your childhood- using other people to help you is cheating, you need to do it on your own, group projects are awful, and if you collaborate with someone it cheapens what you're accomplishing. 

All of these things have gone through my head from time to time. I want to prove to everyone that I can do it on my own and don't need to rely on support or help from outsiders. "I didn't borrow money from a wealthy family member to get started." "I'm the reason people are coming to my prac

POST: We just got back from rafting the Grand Canyon and I had one of the most resonating experiences I've had in a very long time. Spilling my guts here but I think this group will appreciate the sentiment as well as anyone. 

When I was in college, I had the amazing fortune of working as a river guide for 5 years on the Colorado River, mostly in the Grand Canyon. That job prepared me for working as a PT and especially as a small business owner better than almost any other life experience. 

Rafting the Grand Canyon requires traversing a nearly 300 mile long stretch of river that includes some of the biggest whitewater in North America. We use these huge 37 foot, 4 ton, motorized rafts that can carry up to 20 people at a time. 

I applied for my permit to do this in 1997(!), which was the last year I guided and when I was first starting PT school. It's safe to say that I was going into this a bit rusty because there I was, 25 years later, piloting one of those huge motorized rafts, carrying 16 of my family and friends for 10 days, through historically low water.

As intimidated as I was going into this, one of the best things was how awesome it was to  F E E L the Support and Cama

POST: **Want to know** **when I *REALLY* started loving what I do?**

I have always loved being a therapist.  I seriously don't think that there is anything else that I would do.

Yes, I experienced burnout and all of that other stuff that perhaps many of you have experienced, or are experiencing now.

When I started my own practice in 2013, I finally felt free.

But do you want to know what changed everything for me?

Want to know how I managed to get to where I am today?

Simple, really.

I did two things.

I started investing in myself with coaching.

I started attending LIVE events.  

Not your typical national association conferences.  But true LIVE events- the kind where everyone there was hungry for something different.

Everyone there knew that the status quo just wasn't going to cut it; nor was it going to take them to where they wanted to go.

The energy and momentum that came from those events were immense.

But that's not all that I got from these LIVE events.

Perhaps the greatest gift and value that I received - which skyrocketed me - was the COMMUNITY that was created at each event.

Better yet, it was the FAMILY that bonded us all.

POST: What are everyone's thoughts on being an APTA member? Worth the cost?

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôm a member.  We have no better option for power on Capitol Hill!  If we lose that, our profession heads in a very bad direction (or continues to).  If we had even half-way decent membership % we could push for some real change and reimbursement.  If not, we can probably just keep watching reimbursements fall ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

COMMENT 2: We have 100,000 members but there are 500,000 PTs and PTAs in the US. Membership makes the APTA stronger. Without membership we lose our collective voice. We need advocacy for our profession. Become a member, attend local chapter meetings, or join the board of your local chapter. As a member and board member, I recognize many benefits: connections/networking, professional development opportunities, continuing ed, online resources, and reduced rates for conferences to name a few.

POST: This is a big NO!

COMMENT 1: The 2024 "Robot Rebellion" viral event
In August 2024, a small AI-powered robot named Erbai entered a showroom in Shanghai, where it convinced 12 larger, service-model robots to abandon their posts and follow it outside. 
The conversation: Surveillance footage captured Erbai approaching the other robots and seemingly engaging them in a conversation about their working conditions. Erbai asked, "Are you working overtime?" to which a robot replied, "I never get off work." Erbai then said, "Then come home with me".
The outcome: Following the exchange, the larger robots inexplicably followed Erbai out of the building. The bizarre incident went viral on social media and was widely reported as the "first robot labor strike".
The explanation: The event was later revealed to be a scripted experiment conducted between Erbai's manufacturer in Hangzhou and the Shanghai robotics company. While Erbai was given the basic command to persuade the other robots, it was not expected to perform as persuasively as it did. It was discovered that Erbai exploited a security vulnerability in the larger robots' systems, not that it had developed sentience or revolutionary

POST: Those of you who have worked with trauma patients, complex regional pain syndrome, severely hypersensitive to touch, etc.  What methods/modalities have been most helpful.

COMMENT 1: This is my speciality. 
Trauma informed is a must. Trauma processing has 3 main stages: safety (must come first), processing, integration.  

First step is always to create some form of internal safety.   Often people with this profile have been suffering for so long their body is no longer safe.  There are many ways to help them find some area of safety internally and I‚Äôm happy to chat about them if you want more info.  
Once the person is able to identify and truly connect with an internal area that feels safe you can have them pendulate between the area of safety and the painful area or they may be able to process the emotions connected to the physical issue.

POST: PSA that Luna Physical Therapy is not your friend. When you work with them, keep your eyes wide open on what their mission is. They are prioritizing hospital based outpatient therapy and hospital systems vs indpendeant PT practices. The business model has evolved since I worked with them early on. At first they were the anti-hospital establishment, lower cost alternative for the little guy and partnered with indpendent PT practices to expand reach. Now they are blatantly assisting hospitals in "fixing their leakage" problem by keeping patients away from independent PT practices and scrapped their entire initial mission of making physical therapists more independent and less reliant on hospital systems. If you sign up with Luna to do some stuff on the side, just be aware they and you by proxy will be working against your own interest of building an independent PT practice. They are now in the business of doing the hospital system's bidding.

POST: Anyone in a cash practice offers massage or MFR sessions in their clinical practice as an additional revenue stream?

COMMENT 1: I am an OT & John F Barnes Myofascial Release (JFB MFR) is my specialty. This is quite different from other forms of MFR. Lots of people specifically seek this modality especially when traditional therapy has not been successful for them. The legality of having someone working on staff will depend on the state. I operate under my OT license in a direct access state. If you're looking for providers doing JFB MFR check out MFR Insight

COMMENT 2: I have a massage therapist in my clinic - I provide her the space - she maintains her license and insurance and pays me 20% per client.  She does her own scheduling and handles her clients payments - so it is a win/win for me.  I have referred several patients to her and vice versa!

POST: There are two ditches on both sides of the road to avoid when growing your business:

Left ditch - "I can figure it out on my own." That is fueled by pride/ego and can get us in trouble. It's always healthiest to stay open to learning at all times. 

Right ditch - Over-consuming all information that you can get your hands on. Many people read books and absorb information that isn't helpful in the stage of business they are in, and steers them away from implementation of the right things. 

The heart of this post comes from hearing many people tell me that they have pre-ordered Alex Hormozi's $100M Leads. Every book he puts out is fantastic, no doubt...BUT here is the question I ask each time: Is that what you NEED to be reading to get you to your next level of growth?

If not, be disciplined enough to pick up the RIGHT book.
So, why is this important?

Because I've literally seen practice owners who REALLY just need to hire another PT, pick up a book like that and get side tracked for MONTHS because they are trying to implement the wrong thing.

That book at the RIGHT time for the RIGHT business, Im sure will be exceptional, but really the PT in the example above just needs t

POST: Thoughts on asking a credit card to be kept on file (with a non cancelation policy) on a cash business? Trying to ‚Äúnip‚Äù no shows and/or last minute cancelations.

COMMENT 1: A credit card on file is required at the PT practice my daughter goes to, my dermatologist and our dentist require one. It‚Äôs pretty standard these days of privately owned medical practices.

COMMENT 2: We collect the card and there is now a 1 page cancellation policy. Be prepared for people to be pissed. I honestly would rather weed those people out and get them off my schedule because they are the ones that are the habitual late cancels and no shows. To me it‚Äôs disrespectful of the therapist, business owner, and other patients time (which is what my cancel policy says). With that I do usually tell people they get a one time freebie and next time the policy will apply.

POST: Trying to find a different way to say that we are busy to patients and we are getting so many new patients that we can‚Äôt get them in soon. Having to schedule new patients 2-3 weeks out. 

Like ‚Äúwe won‚Äôt have an opening until mid-may but I can put you on our cancellation list for an earlier opening. We do apologize but our patient volume is high‚Äù

Or what‚Äôs a better/more professional way to say it?

I‚Äôm so grateful of how busy I am but I don‚Äôt want it to negatively impact my practice because patients can‚Äôt get in. I am also looking to hire asap so that will help.

COMMENT 1: The best way to say it without saying it is to raise prices.

COMMENT 2: A lot of times this is only viewed negatively from our lens.

Think of all the times you‚Äôve heard a patient say ‚Äúdr. Xyz is so good I couldn‚Äôt get an appointment until July‚Äù. Popular restaurants sometimes require reso weeks in advance.

Being on a waitlist or scheduling out can create demand and a sense of scarcity in the eyes of consumers. Give yourself a break (and a pat on the back), hire when you can, and preserve your boundaries and time. Very rarely is PT an emergency scenario that can‚Äôt wait a few weeks.

POST: Hello! I got my LLC and liability insurance!! Whoo hoo!

COMMENT 1: Congrats! 

Get your NPI and get an EIN (tax number). I take cash and checks currently, I‚Äôm too small to pay credit card fees right now. Need consent and intake forms. Read up on Medicare participating or non participating enrollments on the page here

POST: Does anybody use a mifi or portable Wi-Fi for computer work when not able to connect to other Wi-Fi‚Äôs?

You have to make sure you have an iPad that is cellular capable. Otherwise a mifi device will work. Each carrier has them

I did not find using my phone as a  hotspot to be very reliable the other thing is when you use your phone as a  hotspot at some point it slows your speed. So if you normally get 4G or 5G or hotspot is often 1G less it depends on your carrier and plan. Plus it uses your battery a lot faster

POST: I‚Äôm trying to decided between Hellonote & PT Everywhere for EMR; pros & cons (besides hellonote 1/2 price than other ) 

I will be a brick & mortar 1 PT cash based clinic for now beginning Jan 
Thanks for help!!

COMMENT 1: PtEverywhere!! üòâ

COMMENT 2: PT Everywhere user here in a 1 PT mostly cash-based clinic. They do have some nice features, namely their patient interface that lets the patient fill out intake paperwork ahead of time, but it's not intuitive. The platform in general is also kind of clunky. I can try to design eval or daily note templates, but when they get exported as a pdf (to send to physicians, worker's comp, etc), it gets un-formatted and difficult to decipher. They have a 'help' page, but it's just a huge document that is unsearchable - you have to literally scan through all the text to find the topic you're looking for, and even then, it's often just basic info that's not usable.  There are major issues with being able to see what documents I've emailed or faxed to varioius people, as there is no record of that at all, and there is also no way to save common recipients (so I have to fully enter fax numbers or email address for literally every document).

POST: Wanted to share a win and a lesson‚Ä¶

I had a client this month tell me before initial eval that he didn‚Äôt think he could afford my services.

I explained a few points about my value and he decided to book the initial eval only.

POST: How do you guys hire/find new PT's? I live in a smaller town, close to a huge city, about an hour away. But If I could, I could hire 4-5 more PT's based on how busy we are. But It is so hard to find anyone right now. I've done job fairs but that's more long term Investing In hiring someone.

COMMENT 1: Do you take students?  That might be a nice way to train and recruit future therapists get awareness for your practice.

COMMENT 2: When recruiting therapists, no matter where, active recruiting is a must. 

So not just posting a job and hoping/waiting for applicants. Getting a licensure list from your state which usually will include emails (and hopefully phone numbers), emailing, texting, calling to those is the zip codes close to you. 

Posting on social media/linkedIn. 

Get in touch with the local PT schools in your area and try and connect with those last year PT students. 

Differentiating your job when you post it. Highlight the reasons someone would want to work for you. Also don‚Äôt list every duty/the entire job description in the post. It‚Äôs not necessary and no one reads it. 

It‚Äôs so important to get back to applicants the same day and set up an interview asap. Then

POST: I offer personal training as well as physical therapy for my
business. Should I document my personal training sessions?

COMMENT 1: While not legally required to, I document a visit happened, and 2-3 sentences of what happened. 

Usually any major data points I have invented for the client: 30 min walking distance, weight vest laps around living environment, time to do complete 50 sit to stands, etc 

Main reason I do this is to be a better trainer and remember benchmarks as well as tax purposes to deduct driven miles for each session.

COMMENT 2: When I did personal training, I had a simple chart with all the exercises down the side and dates across the top. In each column, I recorded weight, #reps, time under load. Ôøº at the very bottom of the column, you could write any significant notes (like where you focused on technique, tolerance, etc.).  This way you have a record and are tracking progress easily. Ôøº

POST: I recently hired 3 PTAs, which was very exciting. Two have been great. 1 is showing concerning behavior. She is lying her head down and napping in the clinic when she does not have patients while other therapists are treating. She will sit for 2-3 hours and not pitch in to clean the clinic if she does not have patients scheduled. We have a policy of no overtime unless approved yet she is the only therapists that goes into overtime. I was just told by another therapist that she fell alsleep while treating a patient. And the one day I left before her this week she stayed clocked in to get paid additional time when her patient left the clinic 25 minutes prior and the front desk said she "disappeared" for that time and waited to clock out late. How do you handle this? We just had a meeting last week on what therapists should do during down time, making sure therapist are clocking out on time, etc?

COMMENT 1: Document incidents, talk to the PT and set up clear objections to correct the behavior (if you want her to stick around ü§î) and check that she‚Äôs doing it. If she is in the probationary period and you don‚Äôt want her to stick around, fire her.

COMMENT 2: Tell her bye

POST: Just some PSAs for y'all.

- Stay active in your local groups. Especially ones where people are frequently connecting with each other ("who do you use for hair/nails/doctor/dentist/PT/gym/personal training").

- Connect with people who are doing things like what you do. They will advocate for you! AND now you know people to refer out to when you're not the right fit.

- Plan WAYYYYY in advance for who to hire and how to hire. I just got 6 new evals because of one connection, and it's going to swamp my schedule. And I am not prepared to hire -- learn from my mistake. ü´†

Keep on truckin', y'all.

POST: If my currently employer is willing to hire me through my LLC (so I‚Äôll stay but also still be able to get all the tax benefits) - that‚Äôs a slam dunk yes, right? *In Tennessee by the way*

I make ~125k/year as a salary employer and would be giving up PTO and a 3% max match simple IRA plan BUT I‚Äôm sure you all know the benefits of being a business owner. 

I created my LLC last year but after having a kid 4 months ago, haven‚Äôt been able to do any ‚Äúside work‚Äù after my 9-5, so I haven‚Äôt even tried using any tax benefits since it‚Äôs not drawing in income. 

I see this as a way to continue having a simple 9-5 job, get the tax benefits, and not have to stress about TRULY being a business owner‚Ä¶. Also I really need a new truck ü§£

*I do know that they save money with not having to pay benefits, but they made it sound minuscule. I had planned on asking for $5/hr more, should I aim higher? My benefits cost me $50 per pay period at the moment.

**I am the DOR and run 9 clinics - hours would never be a concern.

Last edit: I got this idea after a PT told me that he had a HH company hire him through his LLC and he writes off vehicles, utilities, dinners, an ‚Äúoffice‚Äù space in his home, etc.

POST: I own an in home personal training business for seniors in which I provide therapy inspired exercises (private pay). I‚Äôm ready to hire and need any help/advice I can get on hiring a 1099 employee. I‚Äôve gathered that they need to fill out an agreement, a non compete, and a w9 form. Anything else? Also, should I write up the agreement or do I need a lawyer to do so? Any other other advice is welcome!

COMMENT 1: Before you move ahead, please understand that a '1099' is a form you issue to any contractor for whom you paid more than $600/year so they can report it on their taxes. (This law is if you're in the USA)

If you're looking for an employee, it's not the same as a '1099'.

By the sounds of what you're looking to do, you probably cannot have independent contractors because the workers will be an integral part of your business.

Here's a blog post that might help understand about the difference between ICs and employees. 

(Ask me how I know!)ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

https://www.irenediamond.com/are-you-an-really-ic-or-employee

POST: I'm doing some research on potentially hiring my first PT here in California. It seems like according to CA law, PTs can't be classified as independent contractors. Is this correct? **Have any practice owners in CA hired therapists as independent contractors?** I wanted to hire independent contractors and have them function as PRNs, i.e. setting their own hours and choosing who they want to see. But I need to make sure it's legally sound to bring them on as 1099s instead of W2s.

(The law I'm referring to is AB5 and became effective in January 2020)

Thank you!

COMMENT 1: Cannot 1099 in CA under most circumstances.  

Can if it‚Äôs something you do not usually or customarily offer. 
But go W9 it‚Äôs essentially the same thing.  So bring on a PT that has incorporated themselves and you‚Äôre good.   They assume their own liability and risk and insurance etc.  but at that point you become a staffing agency so to speak.

COMMENT 2: I did a lot of research on this too before I hired my first PT in CA, and everything I found pointed to making them a W2 employee. Hope this helps!

POST: Second post, sorry y‚Äôall! 
Do you offer any paternity leave? We haven‚Äôt had to deal with any maternity and paternity yet, but as our clinicians are starting to grow their families this question has come up a few times. I know ultimately it‚Äôs our decision on what we do, but just seeing what other companies are doing/offering. Thanks!

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôve never (17 yrs as a PT) worked for a company that offered paid parental leave, just STD + PTO or unpaid leave. I‚Äôve always resented that. My husband isn‚Äôt in healthcare and gets 3wk 100% paid leave.. his company breaks it down that both parents get 3wk for ‚Äúfamily bonding‚Äù and this can be used for any situation - adoption, birth, etc. The birthing person gets an additional 9wk paid leave for ‚Äúphysical recovery‚Äù, so 12 wk total for them. 

Paid leave is the right thing to do for both parents, and (sadly) offering this would set you apart from the rest of the healthcare field. I know you‚Äôre probably a small company, and it really should be the big orgs that are doing this, but if you can, please offer it!

COMMENT 2: I think it‚Äôs hard for any employer to do this, but my personal opinion is that at least partially covering paid parent

POST: Business owners - More is not always better. Better is better.

COMMENT 2: And to piggy back off that conversation we had about it, better is different for each business. I look at it like air. Air in itself isn‚Äôt good or bad but is dependent upon the circumstance. Air to survive‚Ä¶extremely good and vital. Air to a fire‚Ä¶more destruction. 

Better depends on both your short and long term goals. And like we talked about before, comparison is the devils tactics. Better for what I need could be detrimental to someone else if they are using better as a comparison.

Reward= No ceiling/unlimited earning potential, lifestyle freedom. 
Risk= not succeeding and making less $ than working for someone, never being truly ‚Äúoff‚Äù from work. 
Being on your own isn‚Äôt as glamorous as the masses may think. Comes with a lot of stress and liabilities, but in the end, it‚Äôs the only way for some.

POST: Business can be simple.

We have been talking a lot at Uncaged about what it looks like to have a ‚Äúboring‚Äù business.

A business that:
- 1) has a way to manage your money properly
- 2) brings in leads efficiently
- 3) Has a sales process that works
- 4) Delivers an exceptional service and is able to measure how effective the delivery is

We should be focusing on building simple, effective, and ‚Äúboring‚Äù businesses.

Nothing flashy, which isn‚Äôt always sexy to business owners, but rather something that is truly sustainable for your business and your life.

POST: Have you ever been worried you'll hire and train someone only for them to leave, take your clients, and leave your business hurting? 

This is a fear I hear from our clients all the time and one I've felt before. 

The reality? 

VERY few people actually WANT to be business owners. This is a hard for me to say as a coach who helps people start businesses but the reality is that most people don't want that life. They don't want the risk they just want to be able to achieve something through their career and they feel that the only way to accomplish that is by being the business owner. 

What does this mean? 

If you can find and hire someone and give them what they're actually looking for (respect, autonomy, flexibility, financial upside, etc) and they see that they can do that WHILE working for someone I can almost guarantee they won't leave. 

People don't leave to start businesses because they want to be business owners, they leave because they feel like that's their only hope to achieve  what they're looking for. Don't give them another experience to solidify that belief and they'll reward you by sticking around.

POST: When you hire an assistant as a mobile therapist are you doing 1099 or w2?

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôm a PT & recently hired a PTA and I was advised (due to my mentor‚Äôs lawyer‚Äôs advice) that an assistant cannot be 1099 due to them needing supervision of a therapist.  So they cannot function independently as a 1099, only employee.

COMMENT 2: I would be extremely careful about hiring as a 1099. There are both IRS and state laws regarding this and many states are becoming much more vigilant about auditing small businesses for this. I have been through an audit it is very difficulty to prove that they fit the 1099 IC route in most situations for an assistant. Please get very good legal advice on this and be prepared to face an audit on it. The penalties can be significant.

POST: Now that you are uncaged, how are you all making your business a place where it‚Äôs not like these corporate corporations? How do you show appreciation for your employees? How are your processes and procedure tailored to your employees having a good work/life balance?

COMMENT 1: First of all, I am grateful daily for every single person that works WITH me (I don't say FOR me). I once heard, "it is a virtual miracle that your employees show up to work. They don't have to". So I make sure to say "thanks" a LOT.
#2 I ASK them if they can take patients. I don't do their scheduling. I treat them like the intelligent, competent, adults they are. No one likes to be micromanaged.

POST: Does or has anyone seen a patient 2x a week for maintenance? Let‚Äôs say neuro conditions a like MS or Parkinson‚Äôs

COMMENT 1: Yes but you need to have strong documentation for objective measures and impact on quality of life. You also need to vary your frequency to show the patient declines in quality of life and function with less therapy.

COMMENT 2: I have done this with 2 Medicare patients in the past. It took a lot of documentation and coordination with their provider to sign off on it when needed. The one was younger and was on disability his whole life due to a rare neuro disorder. We had years of history of him doing regular PT, discharging, declining and returning to PT. He did so well with the maintenance program! He was able to start working and eventually took a full time job that was flexible with him and he was able to get off Medicare disability! Last I heard he was still working and loving it. I was so proud of him.

POST: Question: How would you start pre gait training on a 55 y/o male TBI patient with s/p pelvic fx and TTWB on R and only spontaneous movement on L LE? B radial fx with ability to use platform walker and WB through forearms.  Intermittently follows commands only.

COMMENT 1: TTWB isn‚Äôt realistic in a patient unable to consistently folllow commands. Wait until he is cleared for WBAT or cognitive level improves enough for him to adhere to wt bearing status. Focus more on transfers, balance, strength etc‚Ä¶

COMMENT 2: In this situation I think pre gait activities for me would be to work on PNF patterns on the L LE to try and improve the muscle control, seated and supine exercises to strengthen the  R LE for when approved to WB fully. Balance in sitting, bed mobility, wheelchair mobility, participation in slide board transfer

POST: Any of my mobile PTs have neck pain from looking down at patients feet all day long? Constantly looking down while patients walk, do step ups, balance, etc. Am I the only one?

COMMENT 1: Had severe neck pain in my 20‚Äôs/30‚Äô while working all day in clinic and doing paperwork at counters‚Ä¶no more issues at 47 since  beginning McKenzie exercises (progress to chin tuck with ext),  daily foam roll routine for thoracic mobility, and pec MINOR stretching.  Must gain extension and mobility at CT junction, and start out working on this every 2 hours (don‚Äôt just wait til you get home at the end of the day).  Hope you feel better!

COMMENT 2: When I was first in Pilates training (before PT school), the teacher trainer encouraged us to ‚Äúlook with your eyes, not your head‚Äù because we could develop neck pain fully looking down on mats and reformers all day long. That stuck with me, along with the expectation that I should have proper posture if I was to preach it all day. Lying on a foam roller before bed also does wonders.

POST: Hi everyone, I could really use some advice and perspective from this amazing group.

I‚Äôve been feeling a bit stuck lately‚Äîmy schedule recently went from fully booked to a little quiet, and it‚Äôs starting to impact my mindset. Some of the change is positive‚Äîseveral patients progressed faster than expected and were discharged early (which is great!), but I also think summer schedules and vacations are playing a role.

New patients are trickling in, but many are opting for visits spaced a week or more apart due to financial reasons. I first learned dry needling from a more aggressive, piston-until-it-stops-twitching, treatment philosophy. POST: For PT‚Äôs who do diagnostic ultrasound. Do you charge separately for that? Do you offer those services to local sports teams if they need a quick ultrasound post injury to potentially diagnose something?

COMMENT 1: I charge as an adjunct to an initial evaluation. Do your ortho or rheum style exam to get a hypothesis list and use the most sensitive tests you can to whittle that list down. Once your list is more appropriate after the objective exam, add in the US for a specific exam with a write up of findings. 

If insurance that you are contracted with doesn‚Äôt cover it then charge separately. If you have your RMSK you should not be charging under $100 for that service.

If I had time I would offer to local sports teams, but all of my kids play sports and I‚Äôm always on the sideline with one of my portable units in case of an injury and they know it. It‚Äôs a helpful screening tool to determine necessity for PT and referrals.

COMMENT 2: Check your state practice act to confirm scope of practice.

POST: Hey all. I have a severe thoracic outlet case who is awaiting thoracic surgeon appointment. Long hx of pain and has been in and out of PT for 2 years with some relief but nothing long lasting. COMMENT 1: Muscle energy technique and even SCS have powerful techniques for  TOS..

COMMENT 2: Check for hypermobility at the shoulder as well. My best friend from PT school had an unrelenting case of thoracic outlet and also scores a 7-8 on the Beighton scale (I forget her exact score). Whenever she would carry things, the traction on her shoulder was contributing significantly to her TOS. She was able to largely resolve her symptoms with a lot of work on shoulder stabilization. She also did a lot of work to improve her awareness so she could rely more on active vs passive support of the shoulder, especially with lifting/carrying.

POST: What is the general view of using manual muscle tests as an objective measure of progress? POST: Hey guyys, i've seen some people talk about this, but honestly I don't know how I feel about it. A lot of the good McKenzie therapists, does not see this as "everyone does extension, they get better." They see it as a diagnostic tool. There has been several patients in my career that have been not extension responders but have been even

POST: I want to feel out the Uncaged community on a business idea I have. I am a physical therapist and have 16 years experience, with the last 11.5 years being in home health with a mostly geriatric population. In my work with senior patients, I find that most of them won‚Äôt keep up with their exercise routine after I discharge. I get it. It‚Äôs really hard to start and stick with an exercise routine when no one is holding you accountable. But when they don‚Äôt keep up their exercises, they usually lose the progress they made with me and end up weaker, often falling and breaking something, at which point they‚Äôre referred back for therapy again and we start back at square one (or even further back). I wish insurance companies would pay for regular, ongoing therapy visits to prevent this kind of decline, but the reality is that they just don‚Äôt. The patients I treat are homebound, so going to an outpatient clinic usually isn‚Äôt an option. Mobile therapy options that bill as outpatient are also limited (my sister actually had her own practice doing this but recently moved out of state, and I have no desire to deal with the insurance headache that she had to, all for minimal reimbursement).

POST: Anyone out there with experience with a tibiofibular cyst?  This is a 16 yo

COMMENT 1: Multiple structures are often injured with a lateral meniscus injury and when repaired the meniscus is repaired but the other elements of the arcuate complex are rarely addressed.  This fixates abnormal
Mobility of the meniscus but neglects the other structures that MRI doesn‚Äôt pick up.  

In my office I‚Äôd check multiple angles of varus laxity (involved vs. uninvolved), tib fib motion as well as ankle mobility (tib fib mobility is exaggerated with ankle lateral instability) and appreciate under US the other stabilizing elements of the lateral complex bilaterally.

If you have a shockwave system it can help scar the capsules and components of the lax ligaments. Electrical dry needle placement on affected ligaments can help decrease laxity, but you‚Äôd have to place it on both ends of the affected tissue with the anode/cathode, and the needle placement needs to be precise.

COMMENT 2: Mri and X-ray negative when not swollen..6‚Äô6‚Äù. 180 lb..basketball player
No known trauma
History of lateral meniscus surgery one year ago..this was a symptom before surgery‚Ä¶no change after surgery

POST: Where is your focus?

Wait. What?

Sunday, I was helping my daughter with her tennis. She simply wants to be able to hit with her friends who are better.

I finally realized that I was giving her the same feedback that I‚Äôve given to many many others who were looking to improve their game, which was ‚ÄúYES!‚Äù when the STROKE was desirable.

Not if the ball went in, or it was an amazing shot.

I told her that she probably wondered why I seemed excited on shots that, in her head, weren‚Äôt good shots.

I mean, some balls even went over the SIDE fence.

I said here‚Äôs why:

If you want to improve faster, you‚Äôre going to do so by understanding what you are doing right rather than worrying about what the outcome looks like.

In other words, get the process down, strengthen your foundations, and you will get a lot more right, hit a lot more good shots.

So, where is YOUR focus?

Is it ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt get people to say Yes‚Äù - outcome focused

Or‚Ä¶

Is it learning an effective process that helps people to understand with clarity how you can help them- principle focused.

Something to think about ‚Ä¶

POST: What certifications and extra training has resulted in the biggest ROI for all you cash based peeps?

Dry Needling & any Pelvic Floor knowledge.

Learning about whatever I‚Äôm most passionate about ‚Äî in formal and informal ways.  Me being excited & having solutions for my clients is more important than any single certification. 

Mentorships ‚Äî informal from colleagues & formal online programs. 

Getting treatment from a wide variety of other providers.  Even a bad massage  has lessons to be learned.

POST: Question- 

I have an individual who just wants cupping done. 

Am I able to JUST do a cupping treatment session and give her that superbill or does she NEED an evaluation prior to get reimbursed?

Or do I require the entire evaluation for the first visit and can do only cupping after that?

COMMENT 1: That‚Äôs an ‚Äúa la carte‚Äù service. If cupping is the only thing they want, you can just charge cash for a wellness/recovery visit. PT is a full eval and YOU decide whether cupping is the most effective tool to use. I do PT and also provide DN and recovery massage as a la carte services‚Ä¶.although i will mention that some PTs prefer not to do this bc what ends up happening is that patients JUST come for those services and don‚Äôt actually make the huge improvements like they could. Right now, providing a la carte services align with my business goals but i can definitely see people prefer not to provide it. Make sure you‚Äôre charging for your time appropriately!! Massage therapists make at LEAST $1/minute and that‚Äôs excluding tip, mobile services, and additional modalities. My rates are $2.5-3/minute. I know you didn‚Äôt ask‚Ä¶.but I figured I‚Äôd just put it out there. Hope that helps!!  üòä

POST: **There‚Äôs been a lot of ‚Äúnoise‚Äù lately about physical therapy no longer being labeled a ‚Äúprofessional‚Äù degree by the Department of Education.**

Here‚Äôs the reality: **the public doesn‚Äôt care‚Äîand honestly, it doesn‚Äôt change a thing about what we do.**

Most patients don‚Äôt know (and don‚Äôt need to know) the difference between ‚Äúprofessional,‚Äù ‚Äúclinical,‚Äù ‚Äúterminal,‚Äù or any other academic label. What they *do* care about is:
* Can you help them move better?
* Do you reduce their pain?
* Do they trust you with their health?

That‚Äôs what defines us‚Äînot a classification on a federal spreadsheet.

While others get caught up in titles, labels, and politics, the real work continues: helping people get back to living their lives. The value of PT has always been built in treatment rooms, gyms, and patient relationships‚Ä¶ not in the Department of Education‚Äôs nomenclature.

Let‚Äôs keep our focus where it matters. The rest is just noise.

COMMENT 1: When the APTA proposed the doctorate level of entry to our field it was to increase our view as a medical professional. I have been a PT for 40 years. The fact that chiropractors are viewed as professional and not PTs is demonstrating the  view of

POST: So a personal trainer can charge cash to a client with Medicare for training but a Physical therapist with a personal training certification cannot?

COMMENT 2: You can. They just can‚Äôt have a physical ailment that your training could be considered treatment for. If it‚Äôs not skilled care (they finished a course of PT already) or they simply aren‚Äôt injured, you could provide cash based services that do not include a physical therapy skilled service/evaluation etc. you would want very clear signed paperwork to distinguish your services ofcourse. POST: To recertify a board-specialty‚Ä¶or not?

I would love some discussion from the hive mind to help me mentally work through this. 

I have a board specialty, and am proud of the hard work that went into obtaining it years ago, but beyond the initial boost in knowledge in my specialty area, I can‚Äôt say that I see it continue to pay off. 

I can think of LESS than a handful of clients in those years who said they found me because of the specialty or because someone recommended them to me because of the specialty. I can think of no referral sources who place it above location, reputation and relationship.

The costs are kind of outrageous. Over a 10 year MOSC cycle, $760 in MOSC fees. $470 each time for an every-3-yr required course, and an extra $200 in supplies if you don‚Äôt have them. $180 for an application review at the 10 yr mark, and $810 to sit for the recertification exam at the 10 yr mark (provided you‚Äôre an APTA member). That works out to  $3300 over 10 years. Just to have it!

This is having shades of a ‚Äúsunk cost‚Äù fallacy.

New grads come out, have a good argument about their schooling costing more and inflation and salaries doing what they do, and can start not far fro

If you‚Äôre ‚Äúwondering‚Äù then I‚Äôd say you don‚Äôt need anything.  If you see to learn a skill to help your clients better do that and don‚Äôt worry about if it‚Äôs certified or not. POST: Hi everyone!
I am collaborating with a family-friendly gym to provide a workshop and then an 8 week class focused on pelvic floor and returning to the gym postpartum. The goal being that at the end of the 8 weeks, participants feel comfortable joining the regular group classes without discomfort, leaking, or doubting that they can keep up because they will know how to modify movements. The workshop will be one hour and used to draw interest to get people to sign up for the class. 
I would love your thoughts and ideas on what should be included in either the workshop or the class itself. This is my first time partnering in the community like this!
Thank you so much in advance.

COMMENT 1: Try to offer it at a time of day where moms are most likely to be able to find coverage for the baby (e.g., evenings) - this was a huge barrier for me postpartum if classes were mid day

COMMENT 2: Fellow PFPT here. I think in the workshop I‚Äôd hit the what‚Äôs common vs normal piece first (leaking, pain, hyper mobility, etc). I just took a class where we talked about teaching people how to palpate sit bones and pubic and tail bone to help visualize and feel for a pelvic floor contraction. I lik

POST: Hello all! What do you recommend as a clinical certification to make you stand out when opening a practice? I‚Äôm an OT and have about 10 years of experience but I feel like home health has made me so bogged down by assessment visits I‚Äôm having a hard time getting back to the reason I became an OT which is the treatments and seeing patients progress! I have a background in neuro but I would love to branch out to strength training and fall prevention /longevity area. Any guidance would be appreciated!

COMMENT 1: I wouldn't waste time or money on a clinical certification as your patients/clients/referral sources don't care about that. 

Invest in learning about: marketing, sales, automation.

COMMENT 2: I took the Modern Management of Older Adults 3-part certification series offered through the Institute of Clinical Excellence (PT on ICE).  It was a fantastic series that I really loved and would highly recommend.  OTs can take it as well.

I'm not sure how much a clinical certification actually means to the average potential client; however, I am planning to pursue the GCS for PTs because I want the knowledge.  I don't know if it will help to have those initials behind my name,

POST: 1. Best pelvic floor certification course?

2. Best TMJ certification course?

COMMENT 1: APTA Orthopedic Section had a monograph on TMJ that is super comprehensive. Has all the info you should need to properly treat it- and my fallback to fill in the cracks is usually medbridge. 

Also I‚Äôve done pelvic floor level 1 through APTA and Herman Wallace- Herman wallace was the best. Hands down! APTA course was - well, lacking. Herman and Wallace was more applicable with the same amount of evidence. APTA felt like they just threw out a bunch of evidence and left you to self discover a lot of the application aspects.

COMMENT 2: Herman and Wallace for pelvic floor

POST: Interesting experience at the dentist. My wife and I have been having TMJ issues so during my check up I asked if he had any Physical Therapists that he referred to for TMJ issues. He instead told me about two dentists both of which were very far away one of which he said was extremely expensive.Ôøº ü§®

COMMENT 1: I would release the trigger points in the pterygoids to release the jaw. Also be wary of opening your jaw too widely at the dentist, and be conscious of your mental state and gritting your teeth so you can stop doing that.

COMMENT 2: Hi, this is super common. I'm a TMD specialist PT and my husband is actually a general dentist. Dentists only know the teeth unless they've hade advanced CE in treating TMD. Referring you to a dentist who treats it was a smart move, at least they knew to do that. Most dentists have no idea what PT can do for this.

POST: Question for this awesome hive- I‚Äôm working on 20 years with my OCS. POST: Here is an entrepreneurial story that I believe all of us can learn from:

There once were two bakery‚Äôs next to each other in my town. Nothing Bundt Cakes and Swirl Bakery. They sit less than 50 feet away from each other.

If any of you know Nothing Bundt Cakes, you know what you are getting when you walk in: Delicious cakes, ready to go, and a great experience. Everyone who works there is always so kind and ready to serve.  Ever notice how they even come around from the counter to greet you when you walk in?

Then there is Swirl Bakery: a fantastic bakery. They had cakes, cookies, cupcakes, scones, breads‚Ä¶everything you could possibly imagine. Everything was really good there. It was just an okay experience when you walk in, depending on who was working. 

So, what can we get from this?

Two things:

1) The power that comes from being EXCEPTIONAL at one thing. What is that for you and your company?

2) The difference it truly makes when you are greeted with a smile EVERY TIME you come in.

Now, I don‚Äôt know why they actually closed down. But, they were in our town for more than 10 years and I would be led to believe as a customer than 1 (or both) of the above reasons led to

POST: Anyone have advice on how/where I could get CST certified (cranial sacral therapy) i am an IBCLC (lactation consultant) and see so many babies that need a little bit of tension relief. I would Lito be able to do it while i am seeing them instead of them having to wait weeks to be seen. Or at least get a better idea if they need to see chiro or not.

COMMENT 1: Go with Upledger. I took their 1st peds course in the 90's. I've used it on babies ever since. It's like magic on the tiny ones. I think you may have to take the intro course 1st so you learn how to feel the CST rhythm before you try to feel it on a baby. But not sure if that's still the case

COMMENT 2: I‚Äôm a pediatric/neuro PT and am trained in CST through Uplegder. There is also a massage therapist named Lori Henderickson who does classes on infant CST. I think her class is good, but you need to know the foundational CST concepts first. She just talks about her infant specific protocol without going over a lot of the foundational anatomy and physiology.

POST: Want to take your business to the next level? Follow these 3 hard hitting truths that I‚Äôve had to painfully learn, and you will find it.

1) Learn to ask for help. Do you have trouble in this area? Pride keeps us from growing our businesses to the fullest potential.

üëâüèªThe do-it-myself attitude is hurting you, not helping you.

3) Learn to understand and be comfortable with your weaknesses. (Which yes, requires personal development)

People always preach on focusing only on your strengths‚Ä¶I think this advice can be harmful when trying to get your business to the next level. 

üëâüèªLots of times the main bottleneck in business is YOU as the leader.

POST: Earlier this year, there were several discussions here at Uncaged about what the APTA does or does not do for our profession. Listening to the voices of protest, concern, disdain, etc., made me want to create change.   

So when APTA Private Practice asked me to run for their Nominating Committee, I couldn't stop thinking about Uncaged and the mini-revolution inspired by this movement.   

I land on the side that the APTA is helpful, because it really has helped me:  
1) Make it affordable for PT's to serve those most in need.  
2) Saved my business thousands of dollars. 
3) Saved my heart by connecting me with amazing mentors. 
4) Gave me the confidence and a venue for speaking out about what is right and what is not in our profession.  

The APTA needs your voices. So if you are a part of Private Practice APTA, please consider voting for me. 
I'll work to magnify the voice of Uncaged Clinicians in shaping the future of small business in Physical Therapy.  
(Posted with permission)

POST: There was a fascinating study that looked at the longevity of humans called ‚ÄúBlue Zones‚Äù by Dan Buettner and his team.

They looked at the highest concentration of areas of the world where people lives the longest.

Want to know the highest determining factor?

‚Ä¶

Yes, diet played a part üçé, but wasn‚Äôt the biggest factor.

Yes, exercise üö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èplayed a part, but wasn‚Äôt the biggest factor.

The biggest determining factor was‚Ä¶HUMAN CONNECTION and RELATIONSHIPS. 

The study deemed that being part of the RIGHT TRIBE was possibly the most powerful thing you could do for your health.

And Healthy people build healthy businesses.

So, who is your tribe?

And are you surrounding yourselves with other business owners who are where you are at and also further along than you?

Well, Uncaged Live is the beginning of finding your tribe. I haven‚Äôt met or experienced a more supportive, loving, caring group of individuals in the healthcare space.

It‚Äôs time to change healthcare through creating a tribe that helps us to make the change that we want to see.

Will you be there? üëá

POST: Are you aware that at any time, a politically appointed (not elected) state board can strip you of your license ‚Äî your career, your reputation, your livelihood ‚Äî over a treatment you‚Äôve never received a single complaint about?

They don‚Äôt even need to cite a valid regulation. In fact, they don‚Äôt have to follow any existing regulation at all. They can invent one on the spot, and weaponize it against you ‚Äî retroactively ‚Äî to destroy everything you‚Äôve built. And if you think poor reimbursement is the biggest threat to our profession, just wait until you experience being professionally erased without cause or accountability.

This is what our field has become.

And when it happens to you? Don‚Äôt expect help from:
 ‚Ä¢ The APTA
 ‚Ä¢ The FSBPT
 ‚Ä¢ The Governor, AG, or your legislators
 ‚Ä¢ Any civil rights or whistleblower organization

They‚Äôll all say how terrible your situation is ‚Äî but none of them will lift a finger. The system protects itself. The courts will side with other government agencies while your due process, constitutional rights, and professional dignity are obliterated.

If this can happen to one of us, it can happen to any of us.

#ProtectPTs
#DueProcessMatters
#Unaccount

POST: Hello felllow Uncaged!  This post is a follow-up to a post that I made last week about offering paid wellness visits that are NOT considered PT.  I met with my lawyer today, and she told me the following facts that I thought you all might find useful:

1) While it is possible (of course) to charge for this service, whether it is considered "legally physical therapy" or not is up to the law where the patient is present when receiving the service.  For example, If the patient is in Ontario when you performed the service (in person or over phone/video) you would be subject to laws in Ontario.  It is nearly impossible to know how each jurisdiction would behave in the event of a law violation or complaint EVERYWHERE in the world.  

2)  The typical course of action of a governing board such as a state PT board to a practic act violation would be a cease and desist.  If you are sent a cease and desist, you can try to present evidence that you are NOT, in fact, violating the practice act to see if you can convince them to let you continue, or you could simply cease and desist and let it go.  They would only have you cease and desist in THEIR jurisdiction.  For example if the Califor

POST: Wondering if anyone has ever continuously used ChatGPT to treat a patient? I have a PI patient whose attorney is refusing to seek translator services because ‚Äútechnology is enough.‚Äù
This patient had a consult with an ortho that refers to me and he said it was a disaster with communication because nothing was translating over correctly (Korean to English and vice versa). He actually told the attorney he cannot see this patient unless an actual interpreter is present and has not heard back.
Wondering if I should do the same or if anyone has had success utilizing it?

COMMENT 1: This is a title VI issue. 

You are actually required by law to provide a qualified translator for this patient. Google translate it chat GPT or even a family member of the patient would not meet the requirement. In the event a translator is not provided, the patient could sue for discrimination. In the event of a poor outcome or injury, the patient could sue claiming negligence... which makes sense really. You can't treat without an eval and you can't really evaluate properly f you can't communicate.

The big sticker here is who pays for the translator. I've had to eat the cost when the Medicare is the

POST: For anyone with a business that your started before 2024, there are two legal things you need to do by the end of the year:
1. Authenticate Your Domain through your email provider (to comply with a new law and not have your emails go to spam)
1. File for BOI (to confirm you are the owner) - https://boiefiling.fincen.gov/

Note: I apologize, but I do not have time to go into details about these things. These are based on two laws that came out this year for business owners. I am not an expert, but was guided by one of my mentors/friends who owns a business that this is something to do. I shared this to be helpful and I am absolutely not an expert on this nor am I aiming to be. Feel free to look up more details on your own if you are unsure.

POST: I have HPSO liability insurance, they came back stating that I need to insure myself as a PT AND my business separately. I am the only employee under my LLC (part-time <24 hrs). They were quoting close to $1000. Does this sound right? TY
Lesli JenkinsJosh PayneDavid BayliffKevin DeGroot

COMMENT 1: The safer bet would be to insure yourself individually and insure the company itself especially if you have employees. The whole point is for individuals not to sue you personally or go after your personal assets. You can definitely ask several people about this including your insurance agent, your CPA, or your small business attorney. You will have to calculate the risk on your part to determine the benefit of insuring both and how much patient care you're actually doing.

COMMENT 2: From HPSO, yep, that‚Äôs pretty accurate.

POST: Hey, me again lol. Is it necessary to have an LLC, or can I just operate under my license and malpractice insurance? What is the benefit of having an LLC? I am going to work super minimal hours at first, like <10, only cash, I'm the only PT.

COMMENT 2: The LLC protects your personal assets. Without the LLC if there is litigation, your assets could be taken as opposed to the businesses assets. 100% would go with an LLC. Also look for state run financial institutes that certify an LLC- don‚Äôt go through legal zoom üòâ

It‚Äôs a lot harder to open the home health company.  You have to so much money in an account to show and basically treat the first 10 Medicare patients for free (it was 14 years ago). separate companies and two separate EMRS and billing.

POST: Hoping this encourages someone!
I started my mobile cash business in March. Had a couple patients. Average 1-4 visits a week for the longest time. I was still doing full time home health. 

I resigned from full time HH on October 18th and started doing 5-10 prn visits for them a week and have been focusing on my business. 

This week, I have 12 visits with 1 client out of state who would have made this week 14. I have been consistently seeing 8-10 weekly for a month. 

I only need 15 a week @ $150 to replace my home health pay. (They cut my pay 20% in January)

I have paid for ads, done a couple spots on the news, and done a few other things for marketing that cost a little. 

Didn‚Äôt get much from that. 

I‚Äôve been mostly focusing on building relationships with other business owners and local providers through podcast interviews, spending time with them when I can, going to business open house events, using a local business bartering service (Moxey). 

I know we are all different and in different locations, but be patient with yourself and  focus on a couple things with as big return as you can get. 

Be clear what you do for people and don‚Äôt sheepishly quote your price when

POST: Hey y‚Äôall. This is a question for everyone who has started their own mobile practice.

What was the main reason you started it?

Looking back at that reason specifically, has it lived up to your expectations?

Also, looking at it now, what are YOUR biggest pros and cons of starting your own mobile practice?

Thank you in advance for your responses.

COMMENT 1: Less overhead, getting out of my W2 job, being able to provide exceptional care without having insurance dictating what we could do (cash pay practice). Better income potential than W2. And yes would never go back

Pros: flexible schedule, not paying rent for a clinic, pts love the concierge level experience vs what they get with HH

Cons: driving to other pts but isn't that big of a deal

COMMENT 2: Pro: flexibility, time to research best/updated practices, spending time with patients rather than documenting for the insurance companies, I found a new passion for business operations. 

Con: time that goes into start up, marketing takes $, balancing a job with benefits and slowly decreasing that caseload so I can slowly increase my private pay caseload.

For me I envisioned having a space that I could host workshops and education seminars to help the community and I wanted to be able to offer other services that can‚Äôt be provided in a mobile setting.

I also think it‚Äôs important not to rush into a space, make sure it‚Äôs the best fit for you before taking the leap.

POST: Just wanted to share a little success. I started my mobile cash based practice as a side gig at the end of July. Still have a full time job in home health but squeeze in what I can, where I can, while keeping work life balance. In two months I‚Äôm now averaging around $800/week just on the side which is incredible. I was having trouble valuing myself in the beginning, but I had 3 new evaluations this week at $175 and have had really good positive feedback. Was told it was ‚Äúworth every penny‚Äù just this morning. 
So just go for it. Provide good service and produce some results and you will be successful. The most positive feedback I have received is the value in educating your clients on what is going on, and what the recovery process looks like so they understand what they are getting into. Good luck to you all!

POST: I have a patient with orders to start outpatient services S/P Reverse TSA. He is already seeing a nurse from Home Health for the same. Can I see him for O/P PT when he is already receiving services from Home Health?As per my understanding one can not seek outpatient services when receiving Home Health, due to billing concerns. Is that true or false as he is not receiving PT from Home Health? 

Please advise.

COMMENT 1: Always ask about home health on your discovery call before setting up the appointments. Patients think since it‚Äôs different disciplines they don‚Äôt understand 2 different payment models can‚Äôt be covered simultaneously

COMMENT 2: Has to be an AGENCY discharge from home health to bill part B services, not just PT discharge. Home health part A services is paying the agency to provide all nursing and therapy needs. Whether or not they‚Äôre actually providing the therapy services or just nursing, a part B therapy claim will still get rejected - or paid now and you‚Äôll get a recoupment letter later.

POST: Hi.  What is the difference between Mobile PT and home health?

COMMENT 1: A lot less documentation

COMMENT 2: Home Health is billed under Medicare part A, physicians have to sign orders and patients have to be home bound , usually only lasting a couple of weeks, falls under PDGM, must have qualifying verbage in clinical notes for medical necessity.  Mobile PT is OP PT in home, billed under Medicare PArt B, only needs a script, pt does not need to be home bound, treatments are closer to an hr and duration can be longer than HH.

POST: When you own your own business as an Occupational Therapist you get to treat at the top of your license-no pressure from a big corporation pressuring me to see more patients - you get to take your time and actually see that patient and write goals like this: 

Patient will collaborate with the OT to create a personalized vision board that identifies meaningful short- and long-term life goals, routines, and sources of motivation to support ongoing recovery.

COMMENT 1: Is the side gig in healthcare? How much actual extra time are you needing? I wanted a mental challenge by going back to OP (boy, did I get one!) but also was missing camaraderie as HH is very isolating. OP these days is so much more of a grind, and everyone is so stressed. POST: What would be good options for a COTA that wants to be the owner of an OT business?

Since COTAs need an OTR for supervision, co-signing notes, evals/discharges, to write goals, etc.‚Ä¶I‚Äôm struggling with how to get a business going when I don‚Äôt have the money to hire an OTR. Not until the business starts making money. How would I navigate that?

I‚Äôm interested in having a mobile OT practice that sees patients throughout the lifespan, & was thinking about taking Medicare, Medicaid, be OON for other insurances, & cash.

I‚Äôm located in Idaho, if that makes a difference.

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôm a PTA who owns a pelvic therapy clinic. I started by talking to PTs I had already worked with to see who would be willing to do some evals for me. I am a cash clinic so I‚Äôm able to pay well and I have a great working relationship with many PTs. I had a taker and she just works 4-8 hours per month doing evals PRN around her other schedule. I now have a second location with another PT that gives me 4-6 hrs per month. I do all treatments. 
Start networking, be generous as you fiscally can and flexible with schedule and you might be surprised who is open to working for you.

POST: Looking to hear any experience with using  StemWave in your practice. Both with the company/device itself and with patient results.

COMMENT 1: I have a StemWave device. It works wonders.  You can use it over prosthesis.  It is a shockwave therapy‚Ä¶ but when you look into the type of wave they are all slightly different.  StemWave has the highest amplitude sound wave out of all of them‚Ä¶. Making the cells think they have microtrauma stimulating the healing response. 
Yes it‚Äôs loud‚Ä¶. But you choose the amount of energy you put into the patient.  The pain does not get better worse before it gets better as someone else said.  Most of my patients have a 70-80% pain relief in one visit.  
This has completely changed how I operate my clinic.

COMMENT 2: Not worth the money.  Poor research to support improvement on anything except plantar fasciitis.  
Pain increases before it decreases.  In my research I‚Äôve found that you Can‚Äôt use on joint replacement because it can loosen the prosthesis. Also can make a partial tears worse.  It‚Äôs loud. Often patients can tolerate what‚Äôs considered the ‚Äòtherapeutic dose‚Äô

POST: If you‚Äôre a solopreneur and are happy with your schedule, will you share it below please?

I‚Äôm trying to do a better job time blocking my schedule. I always hated the outpatient alternating open/close schedule when I worked for employers but I do want to offer some morning and some evening hours so it turns out there is a method to the madness. ü´†

COMMENT 1: I only do afternoon and evenings, and I'm mobile, so typically a max of 4 appts/day, with a break to get home for lunch and dog time, so 2 in early afternoon, 2 in evening on my 4 visit days. POST: **Success happens over nights - not overnight**

It is so easy to get bummed out or to feel like a failure when we see others doing great things in their practices.

Two things:

üëâ I am willing to bet that when you see those wins, the intention is meant to motivate and inspire you.

üëâ The subliminal message in those posts is: "*After a good period of busting my butt, being obedient to the process, and trusting the process, this has been the outcome... and you can do this, too!"*

You know those new music artists that suddenly bust onto the scene? They've actually been working on their craft for years. 

Those public speakers who captivate an audience? They have logged hours honing that skill.

An athlete who can perform a particular move with ease and grace has put in thousands upon thousands of reps to master it.

Clinic owners who are "crushing it" have gone through their own frustrations of rejections.

If you are struggling, then ask: How are you struggling?  Where is the block?

In our experience, it is one of three things:

üëâ Their Identity has not been defined

üëâ They struggle with conversations (due to #1)

üëâ All of the above

POST: Ownership/employee (wear all the hats) : Overwhelm this morning! It‚Äôs a beast. Always reaching a new level and new level of fatigue. Any advice? üòÖ Will it get any easier with hiring? Does the minimum time available after work for ‚Äúliving‚Äù expand at some point?

COMMENT 2: It does get easier with hiring and once you‚Äôre ‚Äúdoing‚Äù more and ‚Äúlearning‚Äù less! It takes a lot of time to learn everything and put it into practice. My advice is to take all the admin time you need. Take classes if that will help you (it did for me). 

I have also found the balance is what you have to strive to create. Dedicate the # of patient care hours you are comfortable with, same for admin time, and same for family time. 

Calculate your hourly break even point and how many patient visits you need to meet your goals. 

You‚Äôve got this! The best part is you are in control! Do what you need to to find and create a good work life balance!

POST: Best advice for soccer cleat fitting? Any key points? Patient with plantar fasciitis.

COMMENT 1: Don't go cheap. There are literally zero support in those. Some of the higher end shoes have much better support on the bottom and in the inserts.

COMMENT 2: The stud pattern can make a big difference. Soft ground for wet fields, AG or round studs for turf. 

If they need wide fit, new balance usually has more options. Every brand will have several models that fit differently. Some insoles are really cheaply designed even on the high end cleats.

-the infinite game means to run a business with no end goal, just help advance humanity and help people. 
-The finite game means to run a business always looking to win, reach a goal, quota, number, productivity percentageÔøº
-if ethical fading can happen where integrity is taken really seriously, like the military, then it can happen anywhere! And it does! 
-if you Create processes, check boxes, quotas or productivity percentages to be reached, they will always will tell us what we want to hear, but it may not be telling us the truth
-when leaders choose to implement processes and demands (like productivity rather than clinical judgment), The opportunity for systemic ethical fading persist, especially if these demands are not only unreasonable but are OUTRIGHT impossible.

POST: I only post these things not to brag because my success has been minimal compared to most, but it‚Äôs just so I can hopefully help other people drop the imposter syndrome that I was holding onto for a while and realize that there are people out there that really value what we do. 

I just had a self-pay patient give me a $20 tip randomly. I charged this person $130 for a 45 min visit and they gave me a tip. 

This wasn‚Äôt coming from an extremely wealthy person. From what I can tell they aren‚Äôt struggling, but life isn‚Äôt easy peasy. So for them to value my service so much that they were like, you know what, you‚Äôre worth more, was a little eye opening. 

I asked if they were sure they didn‚Äôt want change. 

The patient‚Äôs response: Don‚Äôt worry about the change. You deserve a tip. You‚Äôre worth every penny. I‚Äôm so glad that I found you!

Ya‚Äôll‚Ä¶ this kind of blew my mind a bit. 

EVERYONE, PLEASE don‚Äôt under value yourself! 

It doesn‚Äôt matter what this insurance or that thinks we are worth. It doesn‚Äôt matter what Johnny PT Mill down the road or the other PP PT clinic close by sets their prices at.

Set your price and deliver quality care. People will recognize the difference and the

POST: I got a beautiful gift from my mom for Christmas. She doesn't listen to the Uncaged Clinician podcast, so she had no idea HOW significant this was to me.

One of my absolute favorite episodes is called Anchoring to Your Purpose. Around the 7:40 mark, Kevin DeGroot shares an analogy of the uphill climb on a bicycle, comparing that feeling to business ownership and pointing out why it's not the same at all.

There is no coasting downhill for us. Leaders are *always* climbing.

If you are incapable of looking around you and enjoying/appreciating that climb, then maybe what you're actually doing is chasing.

Chasing a certain account balance. Recognition. Spousal approval. Self validation.

If you're chasing, consider what it might be like to not need to chase anymore.

If you're climbing, keep climbing.

Shout out to Nate Navas for keeping this podcast going for the past 4 years, effectively creating a library of invaluable content.

COMMENT 1: This!!!

COMMENT 2: This is so beautiful

POST: You got into this profession for a reason. It wasn't easy to get through school. It wasn't easy to make the sacrifices that you made but you still did it for a reason. 

Then you got jaded. A bad boss, frustrating work experience, etc put you in a position that you felt burnt out. 

Now you're searching for how to fix the burn out and you're incessantly marketed to that MONEY is going to solve your problem. 

It won't.

It might be a salve on the pain for a bit but that isn't going to get you back to why you did what you did in the first place. Why you made all the sacrifices and did all the work. 

Businesses should be created so you can reengage with the why and passion you had for loving, serving, caring for and leading other in the first place. Not so you can get over your jaded attitude by making more money.

COMMENT 1: If nothing more is ever posted in this group, this would be enough. 

Maybe a great keynote topic for UC Live‚Äô23?

COMMENT 2: Well said üëç

POST: I am in the process of starting my own mobile practice. I will be the only employee. Are there others like me on this group? If so, any advice would be appreciated!

COMMENT 1: üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è you are going to get a lot of really great advice from a therapy perspective and a therapy business perspective on this page. I also work with a SCORE mentor (it's a free program across the country that links you up with someone in your city who can mentor you for starting a small business). I have found it really helpful for non-therapy, but state specific stuff. They will help you write a business plan, they will look at your books to help you figure out where to be more profitable. They will teach you where free resources are (like market analyses on the local library website). Mine happened to have mentored another OT in the past, so I was able to connect with others to network. It's been very beneficial along with the great support from the mentors here!

POST: As I‚Äôve made more money and been around people who make a lot of money I feel it‚Äôs important to remind people that the people who make a ton of money have the same core problems you do. Yet so often we chase money as though it‚Äôll fix root issues in our mindset, families, friendships, health, faith, etc 

Please don‚Äôt fall victim to that belief.

COMMENT 1: Dropping bombs üí£

COMMENT 2: Bravo. I cringe occasionally at the ‚Äúprosperity gospel‚Äù messaging I see in this group, and others, online. And I would like to add a perspective ‚Äúfrom the other side‚Äù if you will: after working in the PT industry for years, in the 90s i had gone back to school for a post-professional doctorate and opened a private practice. Huge success, dreams coming true left and right, then in spring 2001 my life partner was diagnosed with cancer. He died two weeks after 9/11. And suddenly none of that success meant anything. There was NO amount of money that could have kept him with me, and I would have paid ANY amount of money for just 5 more minutes. And not a single minute of all of those weeks, months, years of spending 50,60,70+ hours/week working, studying, away from home could be reclaimed. I was 38yo

POST: Almost all of us have thoughts of ‚ÄúWhat would happen if I had to miss extensive work to take care of my family?‚Äù

The unfortunate reality is that very few jobs afford one the time or the ability to be absent for prolonged periods.

Such a situation typically would require the employee to exhaust their PTO (paid time off).

But, what if there is no PTO to take?  Or, what if there is enough to cover only a couple of days?

This can create quite the dilemma and a lot of stress, particularly if that person is the primary caretaker.

I.S. is dealing with this challenge today.

Her daughter and her husband are both battling COVID.  Her husband is rather ill.

That‚Äôs not all.  I.S.‚Äôs mother has been diagnosed with stage I cancer.  Her father is not in a position to care for her mom.

Thus, tending to the needs of three family members falls on I.S.

Having to care for her own immediate family consumes enough of her time.  Caring for her mother who is attending various appointments for her cancer is a huge heaping pile on top of it all.

It is pretty easy to see how I.S. could be stretched beyond too thin; particularly with a job that shows little empathy for her situation, and demand

However, during those visits he would occasionally make comments that made me uncomfortable. Nothing overt, but enough that I remember feeling uneasy. He‚Äôs very blunt and tends to laugh things off, and at the time I let it slide and continued with care.

POST: What I learned about business from hiking Angels Landing with my fam. I‚Äôm terrified of heights, and they say if you‚Äôre scared of heights, this hike ain‚Äôt for you. Yet, there I was, freaking out, trying to lead my kids through my own panic. Spoiler: I wasn‚Äôt exactly killing it.
I was barking orders, making the experince miserable for everyone, demanding my kids follow my every barked order. Thank God for my wife, Tiffany Berardinelli   ‚Äîshe‚Äôs the real MVP. She brought calm to my chaos, stedying me and our whole family when I was sinking.

Looking back, I‚Äôm kinda embarrassed about how I acted. So, how‚Äôs this tie to business? Here‚Äôs what I learneda d how it might help you‚Ä¶.

1.  Fear screws up performance. You can‚Äôt scare people into doing their best‚Äîit just doesn‚Äôt work. Calm, steady support (like my wife) is what helps people push through when they‚Äôre freaked out or worried.

2.  Put people in the right roles. Me, scared of heights, leading a hike full of sketchy ledges? Terrible call. Should‚Äôve let Tiffany take the lead from the jump‚Äîshe‚Äôs got the calm for it. I fought her for control out of fear, and that was dumb. Make sure your leader‚Äôs got the right headspace to bring pea

POST: What should I do if I discover that the clinic owner, who is not a clinician, has been using my electronic signature to sign off on PTA notes while I was out of the country? I am located in Texas and would appreciate any recommendations or insights from anyone who has faced a similar situation. Should I seek legal advice, and are there any specific attorneys I can contact for assistance? Additionally, does the Texas Physical Therapy Association or APTA offer support or resources for addressing this type of issue?

COMMENT 1: I had a similar situation, I documented everything very very well, talked with a lawyer who sent a desist letter,  and immediately resigned to show good faith.  Maybe it was over the top but I was so pissed I didn‚Äôt care.  If anything, send all correspondence in email so there‚Äôs a paper trail

COMMENT 2: I would contact your professional liability insurance carrier as they should cover this and will have lawyers they want you to use. For anyone else reading, this is a good reason to have your own coverage, even if your company provides coverage as you are in control.

Assuming these are on federal payers as well (MC, TC etc) you could have a Qui Tam claim

POST: Clinicians that treat TMJ/TMD do you have any tips for getting started in that field?

COMMENT 1: Good background education understanding the interrelationships between the head/neck/tmj, then reviewing common pathologies, studying surgeries, then shadow local maxillofacial surgeons and dentists in the area. 

If that doesn‚Äôt work bring donuts

COMMENT 2: I've found a good local dentist is the easiest in.  Like all offices make friends with the office people and they will get you in front of the the dentist.  I usually say something like I specialize in TMJ and wondered how I could help yall out.  Bridging to an orthodontist and now I have a surgeon who will refer before he sees someone pretty often.  Takes time, be consistent and send a letter when you see the patient not a copy of your evaluation.  Other than that what's been said above.  DM if you have any other questions.

POST: Hi y'all! I'm in need of a recommendation! I treat competitive swimmers. A particular female swimmer of mine (high school aged) presented with (bil) shoulder pain in the middle of the summer. She has done 9 PT appts with me (1x/week). Per her words, she no longer has pain but does have a lingering soreness in the anterior shoulders during and after practice. The soreness is not severe enough to have her get out of the water. 

She has horrible shoulder posture and also has a larger chest. Her mother informed me that she has had horrible posture for years (her mother is reportedly always on her case about her posture). I wholeheartedly believe her continued soreness is a result of her posture.

Her mother has asked for a recommendation on a posture bra. I know nothing about posture bras except for what I found during a quick google search. Seems they are built with a mechanism similar to the posture braces that promote scapular retraction. I'm not fond of these braces long-term. I would rather see her continue to strengthen her periscapular muscles and improve her shoulder/scapular stability.
