POST: As a healthcare provider (PT), am I legally allowed to accept tips from cash pay clients for physical therapy?  How about for "wellness" services?

COMMENT 1: Don‚Äôt tell anyone, but I‚Äôve personally never declined a tip ü´£

COMMENT 2: From the APTA code of ethics: ‚ÄúPhysical therapists shall not accept gifts or other considerations that influence or give an appearance of influencing their professional judgment.‚Äù 

A ‚Äútip‚Äù may fall under that category but a ‚Äúgift‚Äù may not.  

This doesn‚Äôt speak to the legality of it either.  I‚Äôd check your states practice act to see if it has any ethical regulations around this.

POST: 

COMMENT 1: Personally, success has been when I can disconnect from work and give my family my 100% attention. 

For the business, success has been when people tell others about me and how I was able to help them in ways the traditional healthcare model didn't.

COMMENT 2: I was a family wedding this weekend and everybody was asking me how the business was going. 
It brought up a conversation about success and how everybody‚Äôs definition of success is different.  
It used to be a purely financially defined word.  I think it‚Äôs so different nowadays.
For me, I feel my business is successful if it is bringing in enough financially to support me and my family, allow us to do some travel and go out for meals and buy gifts and things like that.  And if it is supporting me in that way without me treating patients every hour, then I consider that a big success!
I‚Äôm currently doing about 1% of my businesses‚Äô treatments and the rest of the time I‚Äôm spending working ON my business.

POST: Anyone have treated pts with POTS  I have limited experience but want to help this patient and her MD both suffer from this. Or if you can point me to go links or educational places to learn to effectively treat this better.  Thanks very much

COMMENT 1: A PT with POTs here, I've used the Modified CHOP protocol with success for myself, but I wasn't already super deconditioned. 

For my patients, the protocol is often too much too soon for them, but your goals are to stay below manageable levels of symptoms and ideally build strength/cardio in semireclined or reclined positions before standing. 

Also fyi: exercise often can decrease the amount of heart rate increase with activity, and increases a person's capacity, but many will still have symptoms right when they stand, or if they have to stand still (store checkout lines still luck for me)

COMMENT 2: I have treated a patient with EDS & POTS it was a very slow transition over the course of weeks and tolerance varied each visit. We started mostly in hooklying-> slightly elevated-> perched at edge of table progressing to standing next to table with frequent rests, checking BP and she increased tolerance to recumbent bike.
The

POST: Best tips and tricks to avoid burnout?

COMMENT 1: I just started following Brene Browns stuff and its amazing!

COMMENT 2: Take time to identify your values. (There are some good worksheets available to help with this process.) Then, ask yourself if how you're living is lining up with those.

Take time to learn about how you show up best at work, and do more of that. I love the Working Genius model for this. The assessment is about $20 I think, and well worth it. There is also a podcast by the same name that is honestly an amazing listen.

Take time to figure out the types of things that recharge you. MAKE TIME to do those things.

Take time to listen to your body. Learn how it tells you that you're stressed. And work with a counselor if possible to learn how to cope with the inevitable stress of life.

Give yourself permission to make beneficial changes.

If at all possible, work with a counselor.

POST: The first thing I noticed was all of the ice plunges‚Ä¶

So, I‚Äôve deliberately tried hard to spend less time on social media lately, both posting and consuming‚Ä¶

A little bit of margin from it, made something abundantly clear to me.

When you scroll through social media land, I‚Äôm struck by the amount of posts and stories about people‚Äôs daily lives, their morning routines, ice plunges, workouts they do, things they eat, etc. 

We cover it with a noble facade of ‚ÄúI‚Äôm motivating others around me.‚Äù, but I believe it reveals something much deeper‚Ä¶

It reveals that this generation is constantly looking to be validated by our peers and by the world. An outward facade of ‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying to motivate others‚Äù is actually covering up an inward feeling of ‚ÄúI want others to think I‚Äôm special‚Äù.

I‚Äôm not being mean, just truthful. I promise this ends very positively. 

But think about it - Men, who want SO badly to be ‚Äúhard‚Äù and to be seen as men, because they were never told by their Fathers that they are‚Ä¶
- Post nonstop about their workouts
- Their ice plunges
- Their discipline that they want to show the world.

POST: Patient fell on ice, with possible rib fracture, male 40yo. No xray.

While we cant fix a broken rib, what other treatments and education can help with pain management and facilitating healing? Should anything be avoided besides mobilizing the effected rib?
TIA!

COMMENT 1: i worked with an MVA multiple rib fx and he felt better with taping especially when transfering and with bed mobility; also IDK why but he felt very relaxed and much pain releif with BLE heels on wall on his back (facing the headboard of the bed); he used it after he was sitting up for a while (he was a musician). Once he was able to contract lower abdominals painfree and do basic lumbar stabilization his lower ribs healed faster than the middle ones; we avoided rotation until it was painfree.

COMMENT 2: I would not choose to treat unless there was an X ray performed, especially if this is an initial evaluation and acute.

Deep breathing with an acute rib fracture is going to be very uncomfortable. You can teach avoiding valsalva with movements to decrease the pressure and advise on supporting his arm and avoiding overhead reaching. Th

POST: ***I literally just had a conversation with a PT friend who is considering starting his own practice because of the direction that the traditional world is going.***

His main concern? 

He said: "I'm sure you hear this all the time: Can I do it? Will this work? I know it's just self doubt."

Truthfully, I - and we - DO get that question.

 *ALL THE TIME*.

Here was my response:

"You are wanting to perform a magic trick - build something from nothing - and you've never done a magic trick in your life.  So, you're wondering if it's really possible to pull a rabbit out of a hat."

He giggled and said: "You're right"

And, like most people, he was also concerned about being able to provide for his family sooner rather than later.

My question is this:

If you are wanting to do something you have never done before and your livelihood depended on it, wouldn't you feel better about the journey going with someone who has already done it?

***With hundreds of others?***

I know I would be.

Come, Launch with us.  

We take off **Thursday, Jan 11th. ** 

Find out the details in the comments below.

COMMENT 1: Yes... It WILL work especially with great coaches and mentors like you guys

POST: Curious what others think‚Ä¶I believe that timed billing codes is one of the worst things for our profession, and we are basically the only profession that has them.  It diminishes our value, and dictates how we treat if we want to make any money.  If I have a post op shoulder patient, I can do very effective joint mobilization and PROM in 15 minutes, but why should I get paid less for that visit, than if I make someone do a bunch of exercises with some supervision. POST: Quick question for those who work with those who have become injured playing pickleball? I do work with older clients but am not familiar with the game of pickleball. I'm seeing several groin injuries and am curious what I can do to help these folks reduce the risk of this injury. I believe there is tightness in the adductors and IR of the hips but want to be sure I'm not missing something else.Thank you for any help.

COMMENT 1: A big element I work on is footwork. Various foot work drills to help avoid the end ranges of motion during a game. 
‚Ä¶
We can‚Äôt change the 40 years of degeneration, but if we can help them move better within the a available range of motion maybe we can reduce the risk of injury.

COMMENT 2: I would say eccentric control of the adductors more than flexibility. There are lots of side to side motions. Think tennis but smaller movements. Lots of changing direction, reflex training, full body twists for swings, etc. Also I read somewhere that pickleball is one of the most "dangerous" sport in that there's the highest injury rate compared to#of players. I'm sure there's a caveat to that stat, maybe the highest rate in racket sports or something. Double che

POST: 3 important factors that helped me the most to grow 2 very successful businesses over the past 7 years:
1. Imperfect Action - taking action even when I felt that I didn't have everything perfectly set up. I was led by one leading factor - I have what it takes to help someone significantly, and I'm not going to delay in giving others value because I want to be perfect. 
1. A WHY bigger than myself - Your reason WHY must move beyond yourself. "No one should seek their own good, but the good of others." - 1 Corinthians 10:24 NIV
1. Being humble enough to ask for help. Asking for help and getting mentorship was one of, if not the TOP factor, that helped me to succeed. I would suggest you do the same.

COMMENT 1: I'm working on the first one...does not mesh well with my type A personality üòú

COMMENT 2: Imperfect action is what I've had to learn to do!

POST: # *Investment vs. Expense*
## ***6 questions to ask yourself!***

*Starting and growing a business can often feel like a financial strain.*

*How we approach the way in which we look at the purpose of the money being spent from a mindset point can change everything for us.*

*It is pretty well understood what expenses are.*

*In short, an expense is something that costs you money without the opportunity for further growth or time freedom.*

*Investments are when the money spent towards a thing, a service, or even an employee is going to reward us and/or the practice on the backend.*

*In essence, it gives us our time back and/or makes us/the business money.*

*When money is on the table, or being considered, a great question to start with is: Will this (thing putting the money towards) impact our business in a significant way to where we can afford NOT to do it?*

*So often, the first question is can we afford it?  That question can be detrimental because this is attacking it just like you would an expense.*

*There are 5 more questions to ask that will help you to decide if the money potentially being spent is an investment or an expense.*

*Will this give us the ability to

POST: So, get this: Samuel anointed David to be king right in front of his dad and brothers. Can you believe it? 

They didn't believe in him and even left him out in the fields with the sheep when Samuel came around. 

And to top it off, his own brothers made fun of him and tried to bring him down. But David didn't let their negativity get to him. 

Same thing happened to me. Not that I was sold into slavery. Lol. But I do have a lot of haters, plenty of people who doubted me, family who don't like me and etc etc etc... Just because...

Here is the thing. If you show that you can ignore the haters and trust in God. He'll bless you in front of those who tried to push you down. God knows how to throw a party for you right in front of your enemies. He's not going to promote you in secret, but He'll promote you where those who doubted you will see you shine like a star. 

Listen, it's important to be respectful to others, but don't let their doubts and negativity cancel out what God has put in your heart. Just ignore all that noise and get ready to see the greatness of God. Trust me, it's gonna be epic.

And yes, that's GeriHab Physical Therapy and Wellness opening soon in Paris, TN.

POST: Is anyone using red light therapy beds in their practice? 

We‚Äôve had multiple inquires about it recently as there is no one in our geographical area offering it so we‚Äôve starÔøºted to research it more. 

What are you marketing it for: pain/inflammation relief, neuropathy, sports recovery, body contouring & weight loss?

What kind of results are your patients/clients achieving with it?

COMMENT 1: As a Pelvic Health PT, I use an inter-vaginal red light device to promote increased self-lubrication and decreased pain. This is really important during peri-menopause and while breastfeeding since estrogen levels decrease (this can lead to a lot of dryness in the vaginal canal). Usually topical estrogen creams are the go-to intervention for vaginal dryness, but many of my clients prefer the red light because there is no risk of chemical SE and they like the idea of not using synthetic hormones. My clients are huge fans and see results within a few weeks using red light! 

Other than using red light inter-vaginally, I don‚Äôt currently have any panels or beds in my clinic. I personally use a Joov red light panel every morning that I meditate in front of.

POST: Friends! I need personal PT help! I was running out to the front yard this evening and while taking a step felt and heard a snap in my L gastroc muscle belly. Immediate pain and I couldn‚Äôt put weight on my foot. It‚Äôs not my Achilles. Currently I‚Äôve been icing and elevating, have a compression sock on my lower leg, and have taken Motrin and Tylenol. I have significant pain if I try any DF with knee extension, and I‚Äôm able to DF some but not to neutral with my knee flexed to 90 with gravity eliminated. I don‚Äôt see any bruising and my calf is VERY tender to touch. 

Obviously I tore my gastroc, but does anyone have helpful tips? I already ordered a CAM boot that will get here in 2 days, and I have red light, cups, ice, a pretty crappy US machine, and rock tape. Anyone else want to throw an idea at me to make this miraculously better?

POST: Reason #1154 of why I love working for myself and providing quality care and avoiding a big hospital‚Ä¶

After my client with Parkinson‚Äôs has been hospitalized for over a week with limited PT due to ‚Äúshort staffed‚Äù, the family paid me cash to come and get her sitting at EOB to finally get her in a position other than supine.

Thank you to this group and its leaders for showing a better way forward. Change can happen. Keep pushing!!!

POST: Hey everyone! I got an interesting request from a potential prospective patient. Curious if anyone has done this before and if so, any suggestions? We are 100% cash based. 

Here is the question: ‚ÄúBecause my injury was caused by a different party, I am working with an attorney in a settlement with the other party. While the settlement is being discussed, I am looking for a physical therapist who is willing to work with me on a lien-basis with my attorney‚Äôs office until the settlement is reached, as I do not have medical insurance.‚Äù

Thanks!

COMMENT 1: Usually takes a long time to get paid from those and they usually will negotiate rates after the case settles.  I would ask if they can pay up front and then they can reimburse themselves with the money from settlement.

COMMENT 2: I have really close friends that are personal injury lawyers. They want to send me patients with liens but I‚Äôve been super up front with them: $150 per visit or I‚Äôm out. They haven‚Äôt been able to guarantee that once. They also won‚Äôt agree to paying up front.

POST: For those who have used the Nubis for awhile, how has it held so far? How is customer service? Is it comfortable? I am looking for a table I can carry as a backpack and easily take it upstairs. I don't want to invest in something that breaks easily and cannot readily repair. Thanks! 

COMMENT 1: I am going on 2 years with using my @nubis-physio  Works great for my patient population and a mobile PT Biz.  DM for any questions.  I purchased direct from @nubis-physio in Slovenia.  Took a couple of weeks to arrive put completely satisfied with product.  Yes pump is noisy for 20-30 sec to inflate/deflate, put to be honest, clients are impressed with the table!  I start exercises and discussion while setting up.  Portability is unparalleled.  In full transparency, after 5-6 clients in one day, I am done setting it up as a mobile therapist!  I purchased prone face pillow, kneeling pad, and inflatable bolster as accessories.  I use them all.  Highly recommend!  As far as the price differential compared to a traditional folding table...in my opinion totally worth it.  8-10 patients pays for it depending on your price per visit.  Can be rolled like a suitcase of carried like a backpack

POST: My dream is to start a mobile fitness studio. I currently practice as a pelvic health PT full-time and envision this mobile studio hosting pop-up group fitness classes at different locations in the community and potentially expanding to an online platform. I have taught group fitness classes in the past and have a couple group fitness certifications along with Sarah Duvall‚Äôs PCES. I am wondering about and seeking advice on legal things to get this rolling- LLC, liability insurance, waivers, etc. I appreciate any advice anyone has to offer!

COMMENT 1: Call the insurance company for sure- I‚Äôve done retreats for example and needed a rider to add locations. Some insurance companies only cover the live class, not the recording or pre-recorded content. Ask a few companies lots of questions about what you would be covered for traveling and online. I highly recommend a lawyer to either create or review your waivers. But it is what you are covered for that will really come down to the wire if something happens. LLC you can set up or have your CPA take care of. If it is your dream, you‚Äôll find the pieces and put it together:) Best of luck to you!

POST: Food for thought... 

I would have NEVER (successfully) been able to run 100 miles without two things...

TRAINING, and HELP FROM OTHERS!

Why is this important? Because running an ultramarathon is analogous to running a business. 

üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èYou will experience many highs 

üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è You will experience many lows

üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è You will have extreme moments of self-doubt 

üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è You will have seasons (or miles) of asking yourself, "why did I do this in the first place"?

üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è You will be gifted moments of triumph - unlike any you could get from doing anything less challenging

üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è You will prove to yourself that you can withstand the storms and be strengthened in the face of adversity

In my 8 years as an Ultratunner, I've learned a powerful truth: 

The best race-day performances come when I've invested the proper time into training, and put my trust in others (i.e. coaches, and people who have done it before me). 

Running a business is no different. 

You want the most enjoyable race? Or you want to enjoy your journey to business ownership? DO THESE TWO THINGS...

1. Invest in the time it takes to PREPARE for the hurdles you will inevitably face. 
1. AND for heavens sake - INVEST IN PROFESSI

POST: Does anyone here have PTAs working for them? How do you talk to your clients so that they don‚Äôt think they are getting lesser quality care from a PTA vs. a DPT?

COMMENT 1: Do you think that?  I employ PTAs and OTAs and have never thought that.  So I would first ask yourself, how do you see them? What makes it lesser quality care?  To be honest, most PTs are so caught up in evals and paperwork, they have little time for treatment.  On the other hand,, assistants only treat, all day long.  They are experts.  But it doesn't matter what anyone here thinks, it's what you think.  If you have any biases, then you won't be able to convince anyone otherwise.

COMMENT 2: I used to manage several PTAs before opening my practice and if you spend the time to teach and train them they can be very good and provide super high quality care. If you can pair that with a good personality the patients may even request them over you. Just like we were taught, they can be taught too.

POST: What is your opinion of putting prices for services on your website? Good idea or not a good idea. I have mixed opinions because some people may be scared of the price and not inquire at all- but we‚Äôve also been getting people contacting us trying to negotiate a lower rate. 

And what is your opinion on a set rate, but also offer a sliding scale for those in financial difficulties so we can help more of the population?

Thank you in advance!

COMMENT 1: I am honestly less likely to schedule with a person who does not have prices listed. Unless there is something else on the website that makes me think that I will not find a better place, I will not even contact. I am not more likely to schedule with someone if I have to contact them for prices. A price will turn me away if too high no matter if I have to contact them or not. Just my personal opinion, but that doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs the majority‚Äôs opinion.

COMMENT 2: I don‚Äôt have my prices directly on my website but have a button that takes me to my booking site which shows my prices right away. I had the same thoughts as you about putting them on my site. I think it‚Äôs just your preference.

POST: Being a leader doesn't mean you stand on top of a mountain and yell down to those hiking and say "YOU CAN DO IT" 
Being a leader means leaving the mountain top to help those on the journey. Because ultimately leadership isn't about you. 
Which is why so few people really want to become better leaders. They want the benefits that often-time are accompanied by being in a leadership position but they don't want the messy-ness and challenges of actually leading. 
Our professions (PT, OT, SLP, Chiro, Massage, etc) and honestly the world needs more leaders. We have terrible examples all around us of "leaders" who are simply using their place of power for their own gain or are afraid to actually implement important and meaningful change. 
We need people to step up. 
Which is why I'm hosting the 6 week leadership intensive starting next Wednesday morning and want you to be a part of it. 
If you're ready to lead comment "READY" below and I'll reach out with more information.

COMMENT 1: THIS. IS. GOING. TO BE. SOMETHING!!!!

POST: Did anyone in this awesome group start and successfully grow an OON/direct pay brick-and-mortar practice without going mobile first, and without pre-established referral sources? Would love to connect.

COMMENT 1: I'm brick and mortar, it's a great base, and now working on building the online presence.

COMMENT 2: I started brick and mortar, OON, no referral sources. Initial start up was $13,000 from my savings and never had to put my own money in after that. Now, I also did not get a paycheck for 2 years after that as I rolled all the money I made into the business. It's certainly an option and I am happy to chat if it would help. I think it depends on what you NEED to make in order to live your life. For me, I was able to get insurance through my husband and he was able to cover living expenses while I got this company off the ground. But, I understand that is not true for everyone. I think that mobile offers the opportunity to put more money in your pocket from the beginning due to low overhead. The question is - what do you need and what do you want?

POST: Vulnerability. 

I share some of my personal struggles because it's important for people here to see a couple different things. 

1.  It's possible to LOVE life and still have struggles. I love what I get to do, I love who I get to work with, I'm proud of what I've accomplished and live an amazing life. I also struggle with doubts, mindset and mental health issues, and have days that are hard. This is life and even though it seems like people who are successful never have a bad day, thats BS. 
1. It's ok for a leader to show vulnerability. In fact, it's essential. I can't do things on my own. I need others to help me. I need to recognize that despite my best efforts I'll fall short unless surrounded by others to help support me. There's a misconception that building a business on your own is the "courageous" way of doing it. We live in a society where individual work is celebrated and using a team or others to support you is often seen as "cheating" (see school as an example). Trying to do things on your own will get you limited results and the primary reason that people do things on their own is PRIDE. They don't want to show vulnerability because of their pride so they do t

POST: 2012.  Review time.

We all dread those meetings with our superiors.

We are required to fill out forms answering questions about how WE think we have been performing.  Then, we are asked about our goals over the next 6 months and 1 year.

After 18 years of showing up to this rodeo, I knew that MY goals didn‚Äôt matter - unless they were to attend certain CEU courses, increase my units/visit charged, and to see more patients.

How did I think I did?

Well, I think I got a lot of people better, back to living their lives, and happy that they had me as a therapist.

However, you tell me, Mr. Director.

This review was probably like ones you have been through.  And not unlike most others I had experienced.

There was the discussion that if I added just three more exercises to the patient‚Äôs (ther-ex) program at least every other day, how it would positively impact my yearly bonus.

Speaking of adding exercises, this would also help to get my average units/visit up.  This would get me out of ‚Äúlast place‚Äù for the entire company.

My director then requested that I start documenting each week as to why a patient did not attend treatments 3x/wk for that week.  If a patient was discharge

POST: For those who have started their own mobile and/or cash based business. Do you feel that there is a need for years of experience before doing so or is it more about just doing it?

Sometimes I feel that if I am going to charge cash rates that I need to have a couple of extra skills like dry needling and/or manipulations so that I provide more than just the average PT.

Or is it just providing that amazing customer service. What really is the thing?‚Ä¶

COMMENT 1: I remember a therapist telling me exactly this. ‚ÄúWork for 5 years. Develop your skills and make connections. Then go on your own.‚Äù

Total BS. 

You can hire experience instead of waiting to gain it. 

In a cash model people aren‚Äôt buying the commodity of PT. They are buying ‚ÄúThe Experience‚Äù not YOUR experience. 

Every year you spend not doing things that move you toward your goal is a year driving in the wrong direction.
